commit_message:
manager:mark a vm that resume failed

as a result, the vm will be  try to recover
the next time the service is restarted, or
until the resumption of normal human intervention

Closes-Bug: #1330583

Change-Id: Ib9ea77ad1f4cdf15d9b25f70b19a06f808087e0f

commit_message:
Only unset proxy for deploy command

If we completely unset http_proxy before deploying, then we also
lose the proxy for the ping test, which is bad because we download
a 150 MB Fedora image in that step.

Change-Id: I7cd4b336e97b82cb356d73bbebf51bd8f36a06ae

commit_message:
Catch failures with particular clouds

If one cloud is unavailable list_hosts will fail and return no results
even if another cloud had a listing. Add a flag to allow users to
pull results from whichever clouds they can.

This is to allow infra to continue working across whichever clouds
are up should one fail.

Change-Id: Ic2bb2a1642dedead73d7c2e4e60ec59ae8299ef0

commit_message:
Only reduce the node vm's when using introspection

We have been removing vm's from instackenv.json to make introspection
run faster since it will only introspect the same number of nodes we
intend to use in the job.

However, this means that we are more likely to hit a scheduling bug in
Nova: https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1341420

To mitigate the issue somewhat, only remove nodes from instackenv.json
when using introspection instead of for all jobs.

Partial-Bug: #1341420
Change-Id: I397eda9c9ae8d63b0d49f42b59b650fa595cc72a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/73/289973/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # I'm removing most of the nodes in the env to speed up discovery # This could be in jq but I don't know how # Only do this for jobs that use introspection, as it makes the likelihood # of hitting https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1341420 much higher python -c "import simplejson ; d = simplejson.loads(open(\"instackenv.json\").read()) ; del d[\"nodes\"][$NODECOUNT:] ; print simplejson.dumps(d)" > instackenv_reduced.json mv instackenv_reduced.json instackenv.json
deleted_lines: # I'm removing most of the nodes in the env to speed up discovery # This could be in jq but I don't know how python -c "import simplejson ; d = simplejson.loads(open(\"instackenv.json\").read()) ; del d[\"nodes\"][$NODECOUNT:] ; print simplejson.dumps(d)" > instackenv_reduced.json mv instackenv_reduced.json instackenv.json

commit_message:
Always ensure that the local lxc cache file matches the upstream image

Ansible 1.9x only actually checks whether there's a local file - it never
checks whether the local file matches the given sha256sum.

We therefore need to set 'force:yes' to ensure that Ansible does the
following:
 - download the file to a temporary location, checking its sha256sum
   against the given value
 - check the sha256sum of the existing file and the downloaded file
 - if the sha256sums match, then throw away the temp file
 - if the sha256sums do not match, replace the existing file

In order to also provide the ability to forcibly delete any existing lxc
cache which was previously prepared (successfully or unsuccessfully), the
boolean variable 'lxc_container_base_delete' has been added.

Change-Id: I988940892c89679edea887716851314fc1cf13b5
Closes-Bug: #1539236
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_hosts refs/changes/39/289339/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TODO(odyssey4me) # Ansible 1.9x only actually checks whether there's a local file - it never # checks whether the local file matches the given sha256sum. Ansible 2.x # fixes this, so once we move to Ansible 2.x we can pass this a sha256sum # which will: # a) allow us to remove force: yes # b) allow the module to calculate the checksum of dest file which would # result in file being downloaded only if provided and dest sha256sum # checksums differ # Currently 'force:yes' will always download the file, then do a sha256sum # comparison between the downloaded file and the existing file, then replace # the existing file if it doesn't match. force: yes
deleted_lines: force: no

commit_message:
Use swap-partition.yaml environment

Instead of using the environment file to create a swap file, use the one
that enables swap on a precreated partition. To create the partition, we
recreate the baremetal flavor so that Ironic allocates 1GB for swap in a
seperate partition.

Change-Id: Ie64a80fe72c7e2f1e6bfb3c3c3da0f6bc561e453
Depends-On: I5cd68c13dbfe53eecf6c6ad93151eadc980a902d

'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2016-03-04 08:02:24.000000000', 'files': ['swift/common/ring/builder.py', 'test/unit/common/ring/test_builder.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/3ff94cb785867382ff6c37cb256d1b0f5381abaa', 'message': 'Add internal method to increase ring partition power

This method increases the partition power of an existing ring by one. It does
not move any data nor does it exposes a CLI command yet; it is only intended to
be used in a future version to do the actual ring modification itself.

An existing object that is currently located on partition X will be placed
either on partition 2*X or 2*X+1 after the partition power got increased. The
reason for this is the Ring.get_part() method, that does a bitwise shift to the
right.

To avoid actual data movement to different disks or even nodes, the allocation
of partitions to nodes needs to be changed. The allocation is pairwise due to
the above mentioned new partition scheme. Therefore devices are allocated like
this, with the partition being the index and the value being the device id:

OLD: 0,    3,    7,    5,    2,    1,    ...
NEW: 0, 0, 3, 3, 7, 7, 5, 5, 2, 2, 1, 1, ...

If an operator stops the cluster, increases the partition power and renames &
hardlinks the existing data it is possible to do a power shift without actually
moving data. Please see the partition power spec for further details on this.

Change-Id: I063fd8077497ee8c14d9065f07b4ec0fb5cbe180
Partially-Implements: spec increasing_partition_power
'}]
commit_message:
Add internal method to increase ring partition power

This method increases the partition power of an existing ring by one. It does
not move any data nor does it exposes a CLI command yet; it is only intended to
be used in a future version to do the actual ring modification itself.

An existing object that is currently located on partition X will be placed
either on partition 2*X or 2*X+1 after the partition power got increased. The
reason for this is the Ring.get_part() method, that does a bitwise shift to the
right.

To avoid actual data movement to different disks or even nodes, the allocation
of partitions to nodes needs to be changed. The allocation is pairwise due to
the above mentioned new partition scheme. Therefore devices are allocated like
this, with the partition being the index and the value being the device id:

OLD: 0,    3,    7,    5,    2,    1,    ...
NEW: 0, 0, 3, 3, 7, 7, 5, 5, 2, 2, 1, 1, ...

If an operator stops the cluster, increases the partition power and renames &
hardlinks the existing data it is possible to do a power shift without actually
moving data. Please see the partition power spec for further details on this.

Change-Id: I063fd8077497ee8c14d9065f07b4ec0fb5cbe180
Partially-Implements: spec increasing_partition_power
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/07/155107/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_increase_partition_power(self): from swift.common import ring rb = ring.RingBuilder(8, 3.0, 1) # add three devices to a single server in a single zone rb.add_dev({'id': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 1, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 2, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdc'}) rb.rebalance(seed=1) rb.increase_partition_power() rb.validate() self.assertEqual(rb.part_power, 9) self.assertEqual(rb.version, 4) # make sure there is always the same device assigned to every pair of # partitions for replica in rb._replica2part2dev: for part in range(0, len(replica), 2): dev = replica[part] next_dev = replica[part + 1] self.assertEqual(dev, next_dev) # same for last_part moves for part in range(0, len(replica), 2): this_last_moved = rb._last_part_moves[part] next_last_moved = rb._last_part_moves[part + 1] self.assertEqual(this_last_moved, next_last_moved)

commit_message:
Adds virtual_size to notifications

The virtual_size property was added to the v2 API in Icehouse as a
"core" image property [0], but the field was not added to image
notifications.  This patch addresses that oversight.

[0] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/split-image-size

Change-Id: I423719a88ba1ef17e7475ab5388fb1720a28011e
Closes-bug: #1554206

commit_message:
Copy unit tests for StandardLogging fixture from Nova

This comes from commit f96ec4411ce89606cf52211061003c14306dcfa1
in Nova by Sean Dague <sean@dague.net>.

The StandardLogging fixture was already merged into Cinder,
this adds the unit tests that were missed when copying over
the fixture.

Change-Id: I2fbe25ec71138e4b96ff175af72a2a56c1c8f52a
Related-Bug: #1551325
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/35/286635/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2010 United States Government as represented by the # Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import fixtures as fx from oslo_log import log as logging import testtools from cinder.tests import fixtures class TestLogging(testtools.TestCase): def test_default_logging(self): stdlog = self.useFixture(fixtures.StandardLogging()) root = logging.getLogger() # there should be a null handler as well at DEBUG self.assertEqual(2, len(root.handlers), root.handlers) log = logging.getLogger(__name__) log.info("at info") log.debug("at debug") self.assertIn("at info", stdlog.logger.output) self.assertNotIn("at debug", stdlog.logger.output) # broken debug messages should still explode, even though we # aren't logging them in the regular handler self.assertRaises(TypeError, log.debug, "this is broken %s %s", "foo") # and, ensure that one of the terrible log messages isn't # output at info warn_log = logging.getLogger('migrate.versioning.api') warn_log.info("warn_log at info, should be skipped") warn_log.error("warn_log at error") self.assertIn("warn_log at error", stdlog.logger.output) self.assertNotIn("warn_log at info", stdlog.logger.output) def test_debug_logging(self): self.useFixture(fx.EnvironmentVariable('OS_DEBUG', '1')) stdlog = self.useFixture(fixtures.StandardLogging()) root = logging.getLogger() # there should no longer be a null handler self.assertEqual(1, len(root.handlers), root.handlers) log = logging.getLogger(__name__) log.info("at info") log.debug("at debug") self.assertIn("at info", stdlog.logger.output) self.assertIn("at debug", stdlog.logger.output)

commit_message:
Store events in Ceilometer

Adds an option to toggle whether events are stored in Ceilometer.

The default is false and remains unchanged.

Change-Id: I9accb679b97cf7172c67f3cd5f218bdaee507c94
Related-Bug: rhbz#1312373

commit_message:
Enable functional convergence testing

This commit updates tests/test.yml to deploy rabbitmq, galera,
keystone, and glance for a functional convergence test.  Note that we
point at a non-existent memcached server, but this can be adjusted to
build memcached if deemed necessary.

Change-Id: I389d23561313882a0c3fb6236159fee71ab54c3f

commit_message:
Add warning about CRiTICAL data loss

Not a trivial fix :(

Change-Id: I8e80f8a39332ce9bb51222525aaae64a1f64e2b2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/07/290107/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: We discovered in middle Mitaka development that it was possible for data loss to occur if the data container is rebuilt. In this scenario, Docker pulls a new container, and the new container doesn't contain the data from the old container. To rectify this problem, we plan to have a release of 1.1.0-rc1 on April 1st. We plan our final releae of 1.1.0 on April 15th. The work going into this version will be: * Move forward to Docker 1.10.z as a minimum dependency. * Move to named volumes to remove data loss scenario * Backport upgrade playbooks from Mitaka so Operators can effectively manage OSSA and CVE advisories in their OpenStack cloud without being forced to migrate to mitaka. * Backport thin-containers for Neutron agents. * Backport our docker integration module to remove the hard pin on Docker 1.8.2. * We expect the docker containers themselves to be minimally modified. Regards, Steven Dake (Kolla PTL for Liberty and Mitaka Cycles)

commit_message:
Add support for Keepalived VRRP health check

Adds functionality to generate bash script which verify health of current
keepalived instance by pinging all available in configuration GW addresess.
This functionality supports IPv4 and IPv6 by detecting needed ping version
using netaddr.

DocImpact:
Added a new parameter to 'l3_agent.ini' named
'ha_vrrp_health_check' which is by default set for False. Designates is
health check functionality should be enabled. Requires allowed ICMP
ECHO_REQUEST because of that by default disabled.
Added a new parameter to 'l3_agent.ini' named
'ha_vrrp_health_check_interval' which will determine the VRRP health check interval
in seconds.

Change-Id: Ic29b11d2061b732d339abd492a18f2fffb3ff5c1
Closes-Bug: #1365461
Closes-Bug: #1375625

This will cause pings to be ' 'sent to the virtual gateway IP address(es) - requires ' 'ICMP_ECHO_REQUEST to be enabled on gateway.')), cfg.IntOpt('ha_vrrp_health_check_interval', default=5, help=_('The VRRP health check interval in seconds')),

commit_message:
Fix service_credential config generator

Use keystoneclient.auth.conf.get_plugin_options instead of
keystoneauth1.loading.get_plugin_loader.get_options to generate
auth options for service_credential.

Change-Id: Ica6972af5e9271cca89d6d7ee56740ed7d7209de
Closes-bug: #1552980

commit_message:
Fix "journalctl" error in gate in tools/deploy_aio.sh

Since Ubuntu does not have "journalctl", updated tools/deploy_aio.sh
to help debugging docker issues on Ubuntu in gate.

Change-Id: I13bb74d256f23c28d97db20cb8f4ee77a1ab3d80
Closes-Bug: #1554724

deleted_lines: journalctl --no-pager -u docker.service

commit_message:
Revert "Use swapfile environment in CI"

This is a revert to see if reverting this gets us back to normal CI run
times. Since this was added due to Aodh in the Overcloud, it depends on a WIP
revert for that patch as well.

This reverts commit ebeca107fc7b439e9687b8f0f26ca82da28f7fe2.

Depends-On: I04a0893f6cf69f547a4db26261005e580e1fc90b
Change-Id: I850a13df35a6bd84f59fbcf03fdcd7e735b956c0

deleted_lines: export OVERCLOUD_DEPLOY_ARGS="$OVERCLOUD_DEPLOY_ARGS -e /tmp/swapfile.yaml"

commit_message:
Only create 1024MB swap in tripleo-ci

Instead of creating the default 4096MB of swap, only create 1024MB of
swap.

We're seeing slower CI jobs and occurrences of the
*AllNodesValidationDeployment resources, which ping the Controller IP's,
in CI.  One theory is that this is related to the recent addition of
swap to the overcloud nodes. Creating less swap could address the issue.

Depends-On: Ia2a10318de47854a9b8932d72243ce0a85603556
Change-Id: I55fd8ff32351e747e43e2d55152b3aee25874859
Partial-Bug: #1553243
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/27/288827/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: parameter_defaults: swap_size_megabytes: 1024

subject: Fix rabbitmq ssl logic
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-02 23:41:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/cd34ba70e27ec82e643c27c911aac245f6792795', 'message': 'Fix rabbitmq ssl logic

Saying ! is_service_default($rabbit_use_ssl) and $rabbit_use_ssl is
invalid logic: it checks that the value is not the ensure=>absent
default and is also boolean true, when it should be checking whether it
is boolean false. This was leading to an error where if the kombu_*
parameters were not set but $rabbitmq_use_ssl was set to true, puppet
would fail. It is valid to set rabbitmq_use_false to true while not
setting the kombu_* parameters, it is just not valid the other way
around. This change fixes the logic, adds checks for definition and
truthiness of the kombu_* params, and fixes the error message. This
makes the logic identical to the rabbitmq SSL handling in the neutron
module[1].

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/puppet-neutron/tree/manifests/init.pp#n356

Closes-Bug: #1356083
Change-Id: I1f4a67c4b8d43670793331254818b6991b8de640
(cherry picked from commit d850c3e34b59c2305901a7692e1a90c0952ae59c)
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-03-07 21:18:42.000000000', 'files': ['spec/classes/keystone_spec.rb', 'manifests/init.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/23cd211aeb58e5be870e1c8d998b43fb4343e1d4', 'message': 'Fix rabbitmq ssl logic

Saying ! is_service_default($rabbit_use_ssl) and $rabbit_use_ssl is

is boolean false. This was leading to an error where if the kombu_*
parameters were not set but $rabbitmq_use_ssl was set to true, puppet
would fail. It is valid to set rabbitmq_use_false to true while not
setting the kombu_* parameters, it is just not valid the other way
around. This change fixes the logic, adds checks for definition and
truthiness of the kombu_* params, and fixes the error message. This
makes the logic identical to the rabbitmq SSL handling in the neutron
module[1].

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/puppet-neutron/tree/manifests/init.pp#n356

Closes-Bug: #1356083
Change-Id: I1f4a67c4b8d43670793331254818b6991b8de640
(cherry picked from commit d850c3e34b59c2305901a7692e1a90c0952ae59c)

commit_message:
Fix rabbitmq ssl logic

Saying ! is_service_default($rabbit_use_ssl) and $rabbit_use_ssl is
invalid logic: it checks that the value is not the ensure=>absent
default and is also boolean true, when it should be checking whether it
is boolean false. This was leading to an error where if the kombu_*
parameters were not set but $rabbitmq_use_ssl was set to true, puppet
would fail. It is valid to set rabbitmq_use_false to true while not
setting the kombu_* parameters, it is just not valid the other way
around. This change fixes the logic, adds checks for definition and
truthiness of the kombu_* params, and fixes the error message. This
makes the logic identical to the rabbitmq SSL handling in the neutron
module[1].

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/puppet-neutron/tree/manifests/init.pp#n356

Closes-Bug: #1356083
Change-Id: I1f4a67c4b8d43670793331254818b6991b8de640
(cherry picked from commit d850c3e34b59c2305901a7692e1a90c0952ae59c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/10/287510/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if !$rabbit_use_ssl { if $kombu_ssl_ca_certs { fail('The kombu_ssl_ca_certs parameter requires rabbit_use_ssl to be set to true') } if $kombu_ssl_certfile { fail('The kombu_ssl_certfile parameter requires rabbit_use_ssl to be set to true') } if $kombu_ssl_keyfile { fail('The kombu_ssl_keyfile parameter requires rabbit_use_ssl to be set to true')
deleted_lines: if $rabbit_use_ssl { if !$kombu_ssl_ca_certs { fail('The kombu_ssl_ca_certs parameter is required when rabbit_use_ssl is set to true') } if !$kombu_ssl_certfile { fail('The kombu_ssl_certfile parameter is required when rabbit_use_ssl is set to true') } if !$kombu_ssl_keyfile { fail('The kombu_ssl_keyfile parameter is required when rabbit_use_ssl is set to true')

commit_message:
Update configuring of Cinder store

This updates the description about config options added and
deprecated in Cinder store.

Change-Id: I2f5bf837f08253b729b1f1a06b2aba66ab285711
Depends-On: Ie228d1d95365e81881691af4cb8b170335a73868
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/10/285810/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: **Note**: - Currently Cinder store is experimental. Current deployers should be aware that the use of it in production right now may be risky. - To create a Cinder volume from an image in this store quickly, additional settings are required. Please see the `Volume-backed image <http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/blockstorage_volume_backed_image.html>`_ documentation for more information.Optional. Default: ``volumev2::publicURL```This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` e.g. http://localhost:8776/v2/%(tenant)s`This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` Deprecated. Use ``cinder_os_region_name`` instead. * ``cinder_os_region_name=REGION_NAME`` Optional. Default: ``None`` Can only be specified in configuration files. `This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` Region name of this node. If specified, it is used to locate cinder from the service catalog. `This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` `This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` `This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` * ``cinder_store_user_name=NAME`` Optional. Default: ``None`` Can only be specified in configuration files. `This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` User name to authenticate against Cinder. If <None>, the user of current context is used. **NOTE**: - This option is applied only if all of ``cinder_store_password``, ``cinder_store_password`` and ``cinder_store_auth_address`` are set. - These options are useful to put image volumes into the internal service project in order to hide the volume from users, and to make the image sharable among projects. * ``cinder_store_password=PASSWORD`` Optional. Default: ``None`` Can only be specified in configuration files. `This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` Password for the user authenticating against Cinder. If <None>, the current context auth token is used. * ``cinder_store_project_name=NAME`` Optional. Default: ``None`` Can only be specified in configuration files. `This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` Project name where the image is stored in Cinder. If <None>, the project in current context is used. * ``cinder_store_auth_address=URL`` Optional. Default: ``None`` Can only be specified in configuration files. `This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` The address where the Cinder authentication service is listening. If <None>, the cinder endpoint in the service catalog is used. * ``rootwrap_config=NAME`` Optional. Default: ``/etc/glance/rootwrap.conf`` Can only be specified in configuration files. `This option is specific to the Cinder storage backend.` Path to the rootwrap configuration file to use for running commands as root.
deleted_lines: **Note**: Currently Cinder store is a partial implementation. After Cinder expose 'brick' library, and 'Readonly-volume-attaching', 'volume-multiple-attaching' enhancement ready, the store will support 'Upload' and 'Download' interface finally.Optional. Default: ``volume:cinder:publicURL``e.g. http://localhost:8776/v1/%(project_id)s

commit_message:
Record all the fired alarm state for event-alarm

With repeat-actions set, event-alarm got fired for 'alarm' to 'alarm'
transition. Need record this for a completed fire log.

commit_message:
Enable role convergence testing against a repo_server

Test uses a single container repo_server and then runs
the repo_build

Closes-Bug: 1553992
Change-Id: I38d8c22d9e7f9dc5ee73e7eb9aa898d98bf554eb

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-08 17:15:32.000000000', 'files': ['barbican/common/validators.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican/commit/365ee1dfeeb3792ba950e961cd5f1bac859a66ec', 'message': 'Beef up Barbican Validation

This patch disallows properties which have nothing to do with
Barbican Object and sets limits to certiain properties.
Passing additional properties causes confusion to the user.

Example: When passing metadata for secret creation if it
looks like:
{
"name": "all mine"
"junk": "some junk"
}

an error will be thrown as follows:
HTTPBadRequest: Provided object does not match schema 'Secret':
Additional properties are not allowed (u'name' was unexpected).

Change-Id: Id80e605fb59c5300e2a78518486f04c238d3dfd3
'}]
commit_message:
Beef up Barbican Validation

This patch disallows properties which have nothing to do with
Barbican Object and sets limits to certiain properties.
Passing additional properties causes confusion to the user.

Example: When passing metadata for secret creation if it
looks like:
{
"name": "all mine"
"junk": "some junk"
}

an error will be thrown as follows:
HTTPBadRequest: Provided object does not match schema 'Secret':
Additional properties are not allowed (u'name' was unexpected).

Change-Id: Id80e605fb59c5300e2a78518486f04c238d3dfd3

commit_message:
Remove external network hooks and auto-added resources

Previously the orchestrator could be configured to create access to the
external network.  This combined with auto external gateway additions
would cause problems with automation tools and did not work reliably.
This change removes this functionality since it was often disabled in
production deployments. This change aslo slightly reduces devstack
runtime by removing the Neutron restart.

Change-Id: I556f1fc2729f1d62a60de24b6d5e9ed473749f9a

commit_message:
Docs: Explaining dynamic inventory

Adding documentation to explain in more detail about the dynamic
inventory generation process.

Closes-Bug: 1554528

Change-Id: I399d703b680f8202407ae80d3b7dac05deb1dbfb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/47/289947/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The ``dynamic_inventory.py`` script takes a single argument, ``--config``. If not specified, the default is ``/etc/openstack_deploy/``.The dynamic inventory script does the following: * Generates the names of each container that will run a service * Creates container and IP address mappings * Assigns containers to physical hosts As an example, consider the following excerpt from ``openstack_user_config.yml``: .. code-block :: yaml identity_hosts: infra01: ip: 10.0.0.10 infra02: ip: 10.0.0.11 infra03: ip: 10.0.0.12 The ``identity_hosts`` group contains the services required for running keystone. The inventory script will define three containers for keystone and each one will run on one of the ``infra`` hosts listed. Please note that any services marked with ``is_metal: true`` will be expected to run on a physical host and not within a container. Refer to the ``haproxy_hosts`` group as an example of running a service on a physical host.
deleted_lines: The ``dynamic_inventory.py`` script takes a single argument, ``--config``. If not specified, the default is ``/etc/openstack_deploy/``.These files are used to build a definition of the environment consumable by Ansible.

commit_message:
Add vexxhost and osic Ubuntu mirror configs to gate check

Two new providers have been added to OpenStack-CI's list of nodepool
providers. This patch ensures that we have an appropriate apt mirror
configured if the gate job runs on one of those providers.

Change-Id: I39d39d413fd4eb4dfa05809c6de12e417f8d0002
(cherry picked from commit 2e6c545590904986ea29ad7c57576962d8f247c1)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/50/290050/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The nodepool provider list can be found in: # https://github.com/openstack-infra/project-config/blob/master/nodepool/nodepool.yaml "vexxhost-ca-ymq-1"*) export UBUNTU_REPO="http://ubuntu.mirror.vexxhost.com/ubuntu" ;; "osic-cloud1"*) export UBUNTU_REPO="http://iad.mirror.rackspace.com/ubuntu" ;;

It is possible that while a dvr port is being bound,
a DBReferenceError exception is thrown. There are many
reasons why this exception could be thrown, for example,
the port could have been deleted, or some other field
in the query could be incorrect or deleted.
This patch catches that exception and logs it as a

commit_message:
Handles db errors caused by binding deleted ports

It is possible that while a dvr port is being bound,
a DBReferenceError exception is thrown. There are many
reasons why this exception could be thrown, for example,
the port could have been deleted, or some other field
in the query could be incorrect or deleted.
This patch catches that exception and logs it as a
debug messages.
The debug message will contain the exception reason, which
should state why the exception was thrown.

Change-Id: I654ac62df8674122b36ec7429a6db8a1e987b182
Related-Bug: #1501515

commit_message:
Add an environment to use a swap partition

This environment can be used with AllNodesExtraConfig to enable swap on
a device with the given label as specified by the swap_partition_label
parameter.

If Ironic is used to create the swap partition, the partition will have
a label of swap1, so that's a reasonable default for the parameter.

The partition is also written to /etc/fstab as a swap mount so that it
will be enabled on reboot.

Change-Id: I5cd68c13dbfe53eecf6c6ad93151eadc980a902d

commit_message:
Check correct minimum size for data disk

Currently we choose the largest available disk as the data disk, however
this may be too small to be useful. This patch checks disqualifies disks
that are smaller than the minimum.

It also sets the minimum to the proper value of 60GB free on the root
disk or 60GB available on the designated secondary disk. The previous
check was 60GB on root and 80GB on the secondary disk which is not
the intented check as noted in the documentation.

(cherry picked from commit ec14005f7608727896ac21877679d825b557a75a)

Conflicts:
	tests/roles/bootstrap-host/tasks/check-requirements.yml

Change-Id: Id225dc55068e1eed2e19e1e27b0f626163f03db2

commit_message:
Fix bugs when running run-upgrade.sh

Adjust the path for bootstrap-ansible.sh to use the correct variable
SCRIPTS_PATH.

Define the missing Ansible var root_dir in deploy-config-changes.yml and
rename it to repo_root_dir.

Modify add_new_neutron_env.py so that it updates the file
/etc/openstack_deploy/env.d/neutron.yml instead of the version being
carried in the repo. Pass into the script the path to the root of the
repo, this fixes the incorrect path calculated by the script.

Make fix_ceilometer_env.py executable so that it can be used by
run-upgrade.sh.

Change-Id: Ied10466c31c1e78d60efc17498daff0d24c2a380

added_lines: date: 2016-03-08 id: OSSA-2016-007 title: 'Nova host data leak through resize/migration' description: 'Matthew Booth from Red Hat reported a vulnerability in Nova instance resize/migration. By overwriting an ephemeral or root disk with a malicious image before requesting a resize, an authenticated user may be able to read arbitrary files from the compute host. Only setups using libvirt driver with raw storage and setting "use_cow_images = False" (not default) are affected.' affected-products: - product: nova version: "<=2015.1.2, >=12.0.0 <=12.0.2" vulnerabilities: - cve-id: CVE-2016-2140 reporters: - name: 'Matthew Booth' affiliation: Red Hat reported: - CVE-2016-2140 issues: links: - https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1548450 reviews: mitaka: - https://review.openstack.org/289957 liberty: - https://review.openstack.org/289958 kilo: - https://review.openstack.org/289960 type: gerrit notes: - 'This fix will be included in future 2015.1.3 (kilo) and 12.0.3 (liberty) releases.'

commit_message:
Add vexxhost and osic Ubuntu mirror configs to gate check

Two new providers have been added to OpenStack-CI's list of nodepool
providers. This patch ensures that we have an appropriate apt mirror
configured if the gate job runs on one of those providers.

Change-Id: I39d39d413fd4eb4dfa05809c6de12e417f8d0002
(cherry picked from commit 2e6c545590904986ea29ad7c57576962d8f247c1)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/51/290051/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The nodepool provider list can be found in: # https://github.com/openstack-infra/project-config/blob/master/nodepool/nodepool.yaml "vexxhost-ca-ymq-1"*) export UBUNTU_REPO="http://ubuntu.mirror.vexxhost.com/ubuntu" ;; "osic-cloud1"*) export UBUNTU_REPO="http://iad.mirror.rackspace.com/ubuntu" ;;

commit_message:
Remove ceilometer in favor of plugin

Ceilometer is moving to using in-tree devstack and grenade plugins. This
removes ceilometer from core grenade to make room for the plugin.

Change-Id: I09f47a8c24ac59e5db840bcbc7970bfb5d259591

commit_message:
Initial commit for bindep requirements

apt-transport-https is needed for the SSL Rackspace apt repo
we use in this role

commit_message:
Add ping debugging to get_remote_client

When failing to connect to the server with SSH in get_remote_client,
it is nice to distinguish the server can be reachable or not.

Related-Bug: 1355573

commit_message:
Add debug testenv in tox

Once we add debug testenv, we can use "tox -edebug"
to debug test cases when tox is running.

Change-Id: I266b521b4d8ab3569e23ad2b2fbd4e498e4043e5

commit_message:
Fix sorting on LC_ALL=C platforms

We made assumptions on the platform for sorting purposes, which turned
out to break with new images being deployed. Explicitly setting LC_ALL
should make this work.

Change-Id: Id65f1bff8e38c777fa406d88ac6a2355d6033d94
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/19/290019/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Revert "Turn selinux back on after cloud-init"

This reverts commit cf85c5ac03637a4e290ccc1eab404efb49e59a88.

The kube-scheduler failed to spin up after that commit. As a result,
the k8s bay is not functioning. I would suggest to revert that
commit first if we cannot figure out a quick fix.

Closes-Bug: #1551648
Change-Id: If7f8164368be3eec39f9a795a5e7748af68a6f48
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/26/289626/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
libvirt: Fix resize of instance with deleted glance image

finish_migration() in the libvirt driver was attempting to resize an
image before checking that its backing file was present. This patch
re-orders these 2 operations. In doing so, we also have to resolve an
overloading of the 'disk_info' variable.

Closes-Bug: #1546778

Change-Id: I03e08fae97416ebe5cdedcf238a06d1b90203c5d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/40/288640/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
go: replication prioritizer

This adds two new commands:

  hummingbird moveparts [old ring.gz] [new ring.gz]

After a rebalance, moveparts will diff the two rings and instruct the
object replicators (via HTTP call) to execute jobs that bulk move
any re-assigned partitions.

  hummingbird restoredevice [ip] [device-name]

restoredevice will instruct peers of the selected device to sync over
their copies of any partitions that should be on that drive.  It can
be used to speed up restoring a drive after it's been swapped.

They should both run until all of the jobs have been taken up by the
replicator, so a large job might take a while.

This means the replicator has a semi-real HTTP server now, and not
just a debug port.  It binds to the replication object server's port
+ 500, which is totally arbitrary and open to bikeshedding.

Change-Id: I4bbb2719657eb84c5191e053a1654e986511bb95

commit_message:
Apply consistent collation rules on sort

The package ordering test assumes collation rules corresponding
to en_US.UTF-8, so make sure sort sorts this way.

Change-Id: Iddc4fa0ea5d4547cd82a30926b49b9b645f7c4cf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/22/290022/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: sort ${UNSORTED} > ${SORTED}

commit_message:
always build release notes from master

Ensure that the release notes job that runs after a patch merges or when
a tag is applied always checks out the master branch of the project so
the full set of notes is built, and not just the version from the branch
into which the patch merged.

Change-Id: I7cbb0f60d8120300c438cb44598b9f7b16e8abe5
Closes-Bug: #1552911
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/67/290067/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - shell: | #!/bin/bash -xe # # When building the release notes after a patch merges we # always want to build from master. Reno will find release # notes on other branches and insert them into the right # places in the documentation build, but only master has all # of the appropriate branch-specific input files for # Sphinx. The branch-git-prep builder checks out the # repository where the current patch just merged, but it # honors zuul configuration variables that may cause it to # check out a patch merged into a stable branch. So, reset # what we've checked out to master. # git checkout origin/master

commit_message:
[Verify] Improve comparison of Neutron client versions

The current mechanism that compares Neutron client versions in the
_configure_network_feature_enabled method will not work when we have
Neutron client version, for example, 5.1.2. So this patch is intended
to fix the issue.

Change-Id: I6bb7c96456207e291ad6b889de922985f58b240a

commit_message:
Remove additional 'timeout' element

Remove additional 'timeout' element from trigger crash dump test and
rename _wait_for_nmi to _assert_nmi so that we get at least one
'assert' for each test.

Closes-bug: 1554306

This patch moves the default_store config option to the glance::api class,

commit_message:
Implement multiple store configuration

This patch moves the default_store config option to the glance::api
class, and makes it possible to configure more than one store while
supplying a value for the default store to be used. If only one store
is given for glance_store/stores, the default store is automatically
set to be the same value. If multiple stores are given and no default
store is explicitly set, the config will fail and ask the user to
provide a default store.

Change-Id: I28a79ae36e673a3537ea16910d338666b65c80f7
Closes-bug: #1481460
Co-Authored-By: Alex Schultz <aschultz@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Add config option + docs for security hardening

This patch adds a configurable option for deployers to apply security
hardening by adjusting apply_security_hardening to true within
the user_variables.yml file. In addition, security hardening is enabled
on AIO builds by default.

Documentation about the security role and how to enable it are also included
in this patch.

This is a backport of Ic05ab7eacd6a1966814764b8290817fb78732758
from master. It also includes the fix from
I2c78f4e913e99e5fc5d84fba9e28197b73ac8f25 that skips the apt key check.

Implements: blueprint security-hardening

Change-Id: Ic05ab7eacd6a1966814764b8290817fb78732758
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/57/273257/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Added support to verify extra-routes deletion

Earlier the test was only verifying presence of extra routes
on the router.

Tempest client provides a method to delete the extra routes.
Assertion on this deletion was not present before, hence this
support is added.

Now the testcase will assert,

1. Presence of extra routes on the router after creation.
2. Absence of extra routes on the router after deletion.

Change-Id: I6f2c2ebdce227705f073a43ff04c8bddc4ca5fd4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/52/267452/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @test.idempotent_id('ce1f9add-f2d2-409b-9168-603cde1b9b6f') @test.requires_ext(extension='extraroute', service='network') def test_delete_extra_routes(self): # Create different cidr for each subnet to avoid cidr duplicate # The cidr starts from tenant_cidr next_cidr = netaddr.IPNetwork(self.tenant_cidr) # Create a router router = self._create_router( data_utils.rand_name('router-'), True) self.addCleanup( self._delete_extra_routes, router['id']) network = self.create_network() subnet = self.create_subnet(network, cidr=next_cidr) # Add router interface with subnet id self.create_router_interface(router['id'], subnet['id']) cidr = netaddr.IPNetwork(subnet['cidr']) next_hop = str(cidr[2]) destination = str(subnet['cidr']) test_routes = [] test_routes.append( {'nexthop': next_hop, 'destination': destination} ) self.client.update_extra_routes(router['id'], test_routes) show_body_before_deletion = self.client.show_router(router['id']) self.client.delete_extra_routes(router['id']) show_body_after_deletion = self.client.show_router(router['id']) self.assertNotEqual(len(show_body_before_deletion['router']['routes']), len(show_body_after_deletion['router']['routes']))

commit_message:
Change policy approach to show image locations

Currently when we specify get_image_location policy for admin,
this policy also forbids image-show, image-list requests.
This makes the policy not useful for users so the spec
contains description of new behaviou to make the policy useful.

bp change-location-policy-v2

Change-Id: I46562cd3b6eae2e4a35d7bdbbb49783a9e078e37
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/87/233687/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================================ Change v2 API behavior when specifying get_image_location policy ================================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/change-location-policy-v2 As requested in https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1502136 this spec proposed the new behaviour for Glance API v2 when user specify a policy for get_image_location in policy.json Problem description =================== The problem is valid when showing of locations is enabled in Glance. If a user changes the default policy.json with get_image_locations: role:admin then image-show and image-list become not available for users because Glance is trying to retrieve locations from images. As a result we are getting 403 error for image-show, image-list. Proposed change =============== If access to location info is forbidden with policy.json then Glance should just exclude location information from output instead of raising Forbidden exception. The similar cases for other policies must be treated in the same way (Right now there is no such cases). Alternatives ------------ Stay it as it is. In this case get_image_location becomes useless because image info is not available to users. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- Some info might be excluded from response if it is forbidden. So when we will specify some additional policies the clients should be ready to responses without some attributes. In the current implementation only locations are managed by policies, so they will be excluded from response. Security impact --------------- Users will see the maximal allowed image info. If some info is forbidden then it will be just excluded from response. So if some users considered get_image_location as "prohibit image-show and image-list" requests then they should change policy.json and use appropriate policies. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kkushaev Reviewers --------- None. Work Items ---------- - Change the policy approach for all items - Prepare tests for it. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= None. Documentation Impact ==================== If somebody will describe policy info then the behavior proposed in this spec must be also described. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Upload retry spec

Retrying a failed image upload results in a HTTP 409.

Change-Id: I40b751a8cf14b2ffb51441cb191ebf16c9a06a08
Implements: bp upload-retry
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/50/206250/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============ Upload Retry ============ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/upload-retry Retrying a failed image upload results in a HTTP 409. Problem description =================== Feature: Reliable Snapshots In order to periodically save the state of my instance, As an OpenStack Powered Cloud customer I want to have the ability to reliably snapshot my instance. Scenario: Retry Error Response Given the Glance API endpoint is reachable from the instance location When an image upload request is made And the image upload fails Then a request to upload the same image will be accepted And the upload request will be attempted And the request can succeed Proposed change =============== A request to upload an image for which a previous attempt failed will be retried. Leverage the deprecation of the 'killed' status [0]. Alternatives ------------ 1. Do nothing: this is a bad experience for API consumers as the UUID is returned on the snapshot request and creation of a new snapshot requires a new UUID. 2. Never fail, just resume: I really like this idea. It's not perpendicular to the proposed change and seems like a good second step. Data model impact ----------------- The 'killed' status is being deprecated and will no longer be used. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- I don't believe this is possible, but we need to ensure that a bad actor cannot sneak in and upload malicious data for the retry fooling the system into thinking that the malicious data was a successful retry. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Negligible Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Retries will work and any workarounds developers might be using can be removed. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jesse-j-cook Other contributors: hemanth-makkapati Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): hemanth-makkapati nikhil-komawar Other reviewer(s): Work Items ---------- Allow retries Dependencies ============ Deprecate 'Killed' status Testing ======= SEE Problem Description for scenarios to be tested. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [0] https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/domain/__init__.py#L105-107

commit_message:
Pluggable Database API for Artifact Storage

The Glance Artifact API Service stores the information about its
artifacts in the main Glance database but in its own set of
independent tables, unrelated to the ones being used by Glance Images
API Service. This set of tables is designed to be artifact-type
independent, i.e. to be able to store the information about all the
artifacts regardless of their type and the version of that types.

However, in some cases such design may be inefficient. This spec
addresses this by providing more capabilities for artifact type
developers or deployers.

Change-Id: I0fe3d93cf07ea08123571a21a03107e712a77a0c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/47/260447/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== Pluggable Database API for Artifact Storage =========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/pluggable-artifact-db-api The Glance Artifact API Service stores the information about its artifacts in the main Glance database but in its own set of independent tables, unrelated to the ones being used by Glance Images API Service. This set of tables is designed to be artifact-type independent, i.e. to be able to store the information about all the artifacts regardless of their type and the version of that types. However, in some cases such design may be inefficient. This spec addresses this by providing more capabilities for artifact type developers or deployers. Problem description =================== Performance issues ------------------ Current data model of Artifact Service is plugin-independent. The type-specific artifact data (such as custom properties, blob definitions and dependency relations) are stored in denormalized schemaless database tables. Each property is represented by a single row of the `ARTIFACT_PROPERTIES` table, and the value of the `ARTIFACT_ID` column of this row represents a reference to an actual artifact in the main table, which in its turn includes the information about the artifact type and its version; other columns of `ARTIFACT_PROPERTIES` are used to store the actual value of the given property. See [1] for more detailed description of the currently implemented data model. This ensures the database interoperability between the different artifact type plugins, as well as removes the need to run DB migrations when the new versions of artifact types are released. However it has some serious drawbacks, and the DB query performance is one of the most important: the need to fetch and join N table rows instead of 1 (where N is the number of the type-specific artifact properties) per artifact may be a serious performance threat especially at scale. The alternative way would be to follow a common approach to store artifact data in regular normalized tables structured to represent the artifact type schema. I.e. for each artifact type there would be a single table, having each column corresponding to each type-specific attribute, be it a property, a dependency relation or a blob location. Such model would have better (and more tunable) performance, however it will be bound to artifact type's schema. It will require to perform a DB migration each time an artifact type plugin is installed or upgraded in the system. This tends to dramatically complicate the deployment. Legacy data issues ------------------ Another problem which we attempt to address with this spec is the legacy data. Some projects which manipulate with metadata-annotated binary assets (aka artifacts) may already have some kind of custom databases for that assets, and sometimes they may be unable to (or unwilling to) migrate their DBs to the default provided by Artifact Service. The most obvious example is the Glance project itself: Glance's Images are intended to be first class Artifacts, however it is very unlikely that Glance Images APIs of versions 1 or 2 will store the Images data in the default DB tables of Artifact Service anytime soon. Still it would be beneficial for the consumers of both Images and Artifacts APIs if they both could be used to manipulate with Images. To achieve this, the Artifact Service should be able to store the artifacts of one of its types (Image Artifacts in this case) using a different database API: "image" artifacts should be stored in (and listed from, etc) the legacy tables utilized by the Images Service, while other artifact types - in the default tables of Artifact Service. Proposed change =============== It is proposed to decouple the database access API (currently represented by `glance.db.sqlalchemy.artifacts` python module) from the Artifact Service itself. The current DB API will just become a default one being bundled with Glare, but any other module matching some simple interface may be supplied by the deployer via a config file. Such configuration may be global (thus allowing to override the db schema for all the artifact types) or type specific (thus overriding it for some specific type). The artifact type developers may also specify default db api modules for their types. So, this means that the db api may be specified in three different locations: #. Global Default. May be specified in the `[Default]` section of artifact-service configuration file. Specifies the default db api for all the artifact types. Defaults to `glance.db.sqlalchemy.artifacts`; #. Plugin-defined type-specific default. May be provided by the developer of artifact-type plugin by setting the value of `DEFAULT_DB_API` attribute of the artifact type class definition. Overrides the Global Default for artifacts of this type; #. Type-specific configuration specified in type-specific section of the artifact-service config file. Overrides both Global Default and plugin-defined type-specific default. The valid DB API module should implement the following interface: * `DB_API_NAME` mandatory attribute containing the name of the API. May be used for logging purposes to identify the DB API module; * `is_applicable_to` function accepting `type_name` and `type_version` parameters. Optional. If specified will be called to check if this module can be used to manipulate the artifacts of the given type and version; * `get_by_id` function, used to fetch an artifact by its id. Accepts the id of the artifact as a parameter and returns a dict with all the attributes of the loaded artifact, or `None` if the artifact with a given id is not found in the DB. Another parameter which may be passed is `for_update`: if its value is `True` it means that the function is called from the routine which assumes subsequent updates of the artifact (e.g. `PATCH` API call), so the DB API may use some kind of writer lock, such as `SELECT FOR UPDATE` SQL statement; * `list` function, used to list ranges of artifacts, filtered by various attributes. Accepts several dicts of parameters to define filtering, sorting and pagination, returns a list of dicts with all the attributes of loaded artifacts; * `create` function, used to create artifact records in database. Accepts a dict with all the needed attributes of the artifact, returns a new dict describing the created object; * `update` function, used to update an existing artifact. Accepts two dicts of attributes: one for modified attributes, another for deleted; * `delete` function, used to delete artifact record from database. Accepts the id of the artifact as a parameter, returns `True` is the artifact was successfully deleted and `False` otherwise. * `get_session` function, which may be called by the executing routine to obtain some "session" object, which will be passed as an extra parameter to all other functions above. All the functions above should also accept the `context` parameter which will contain the information about the current HTTP request, authenticated user, the project id, etc. The actual final signatures of the functions above are to be defined during the implementation of this spec. Anyway, the functions should allow variable number and keyword arguments (`*args` and `**kwargs`) to allow the service to pass additional parameters to the db api. Alternatives ------------ Instead of implementing this pluggable solution, we may rely solely on database migrations: change the data model to schema-driven normalized one to optimize the performance, and use migrations to transform the legacy data structures to the ones specific to Artifact Service. Such approach would be much less flexible and cumbersome for both developers and deployers. Data model impact ----------------- The existing data model remains unaffected. The functions of existing db module (`glance.db.sqlalchemy.artifacts`) need to be refactored to comply with the new interface (or an adapter has to be created). Other DB API modules may define other DB modules and create the DB structures using their own migrations, however such changes are out of scope for this spec. REST API impact --------------- This spec does not affect formal API signatures, however it requires to make an important change in the implementation of "List Artifacts" call of the public (plugin-independent) API (see [2] for the complete specification of this API). In case when different artifact types installed in the system use different db APIs there is no single ID space which may be used to paginate the artifacts, as different artifacts may be eventually stored in different tables (and probably even different databases), thus they cannot be fetched with a single request. This changes the semantics of the `marker` parameter of HTTP request: it no longer may be an ID of the last fetched artifact. Instead, it should include several IDs of the fetched artifacts: one per each unique db_api used by the types of these artifacts. These ids should be accompanied by some identifiers of the DB APIs used to fetch the corresponding artifacts. The resulting composite marker value may have a form of:: <db_api1_id>:<some_artifact_id>,<db_api2_id>:<another_artifact_id>,... This API implementation should be able to properly generate such markers to include them into the "next" URI of the response object, and to parse them properly, so the `list` functions of db_api modules are called with appropriate marker values. Security impact --------------- Given that the DB modules are deployed by authorized cloud administrators, this change does not impact security. Notifications impact -------------------- N/A Other end user impact --------------------- Since the change in marker semantics does not affect the actual API signatures, this does not affect end-users in any way. Performance Impact ------------------ In case when different artifact types installed in the system use different db APIs there is no way to clearly identify which db_api to use when processing a "Get an Artifact by ID" API call. The only option will be to call the `get_by_id` functions of these db api modules one by one, till at least one of them returns a non-empty result. The same applies to the "List Artifacts" call: all the db_api's have to be called with the same set of query parameters followed by the in-memory joining of the results. This may affect performance, especially in situation when the number of db_apis grows significantly. However, we don't expect this number to be rally large: most probably in most production cases there will be not more then 5 different db apis enabled. Other deployer impact --------------------- By default, the current behavior will remain intact. All the new configuration parameters will have meaningful defaults, and the default db_api bundled with Glance Artifact Service will be the current implementation of `glance.db.sqlalchemy.artifacts`, so no additional actions will have to be done after this spec is implemented. Developer impact ---------------- The interfaces of DB API modules have to be well-documented, so the developers may easily create new implementations of them Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ativelkov Other contributors: mfedosin Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): nikhil-komawar Other reviewer(s): kkushaev dshakhray Work Items ---------- #. Design and define the common DB_API interface #. Modify the current `glance.db.sqlalchemy.artifacts` to implement it #. Modify the plugin declarative framework to provide artifact type developers with ability to specify the default db_api for the artifact type #. Modify the configs to allow Global Default and Type-specific dv_api to be specified in the configuration file #. Modify the REST API / Domain layers to make use of different db apis #. Modify the REST API to properly generate and parse composite pagination markers Dependencies ============ * Since this slightly modifies the REST API implementation, it's for the Public (plugin-independent) API ("Artifacts API v 0.2", specified at [2]) to be implemented first. Testing ======= The functional tests have to be modified to include at least two different db api's, so the new pagination semantic is covered with the tests. Tempest tests have to wait till the Artifact API is stable. Documentation Impact ==================== The interfaces of DB API modules have to be well-documented References ========== #. `Initial Artifact Spec <https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/kilo/artifact-repository.html#data-model-impact>`_ #. `Public (plugin-independent) API spec <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/254710/>`_

commit_message:
Image Metadata Mutation

This proposal outlines a configration option for glance which allows
default properties to be applied to an image when it is created. It
is primarily concerned with tagging images with an architecture so
that images are scheduled on the right machine in a heterogeneous
environment, however can be used to change VM IO buses or enable
qemu agent operation by default

Change-Id: I21804aca6dd5bf1eb60b7e7ce5c0ce40ea349de6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/61/249761/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================= Image Metadata Mutation ======================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/image-metadata-mutation Allows glance to mutate image attributes on creation. Problem description =================== Operators who run heterogeneous compute (e.g. x86_64 and aarch64) from a shared control plane may use the architecture attribute to schedule instances onto hypervisors of the correct architecture to run the image. Typically end users expect things to just work without having to specify an architecture explicitly as the vast majority of public clouds are x86 only. The reality of the situation is that images without an explicit architecture attribute end up getting scheduled on the wrong architecture and end up in an error state, causing a support nightmare. Once educated in how to tag the images correctly there is often resitance to change as interoperability between homogenous and heterogeneous clouds require modifications to provisioning software to cater for the enhanced capabilities of the latter type of cloud. Proposed change =============== Observations are that x86_64 is the predominant architecture; aarch64 for example are niche markets. Applying a default architecture of x86_64 will capture 99% of all cases and ensure those images are scheduled on the correct class of hardware. The proposed change allows a user to specify a hash of default key/value pairs in the glance API configuration. Regardless of API version the operation is to merge the defaults hash with the user supplied attributes, which take precedence, before existing security checks are performed and ultimately the image commited to the registry. The solution is flexible enough to not be limited to defining a default architecture, but also IO modes e.g. defaulting to virtio-scsi disks. Alternatives ------------ The proposal assumes that the nova image_props_filter does the scheduling to the correct class of hardware for the image, however a similar outcome to that outlined here could be acheived by creating a filter that selects hosts of a specific architecture if one is not explicitly defined in the image metadata. Applying defaults in glance rather than nova as highlighted previously also gives the operator additional powers to select IO busses or enable qemu agent with what is anticipated to be a simpler less intrusive change. Another option is to have the API reject image create requests which do not contain the requisite properties required for the particular cloud deployment. However this is not a great solution as previously discussed from an interoperability perspective as user provisioning scripts will stop working on clouds that mandate the specification of various image properties. A 'perfect' solution would be if glance were smart enough to inspect the image being presented to it and make a best guess as to the architecture by looking at ELF binary headers, but given the complexity versus this proposal it seems a little heavy handed. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- Although this functionality will occur transparently there is a change request in flight for horizon which allows the architecture field to be altered to be a programmable drop down which is a required field. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- This proposal doesn't alter anything unless a configuration option is explicitly enabled by an operator. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: spjmurray Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): Other reviewer(s): Work Items ---------- * Create configuration option for API * Implement simple filter pass function in V1 API * Implement image factory proxy for V2 API Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= * Glance API will need to be configured to enable property mutation * Images created with all API revisions. Images within glance checked to ensure the property defaults have been applied correctly. * Image created with explicit property. Image within glance checked to ensure the default can be overriden. Documentation Impact ==================== None. References ========== None.
