commit_message:
Glance metadata definition i18n support needed

The Glance Metadata Definitions (metadefs) need to be able to display
the display-name, titles and descriptions for Namespaces, Objects and
Properties in alternate languages.

Change-Id: I473e3ee718e0f59714f88cb17637243dca5a2fba
Implements: blueprint metadefs-i18n-support
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/11/229211/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================================= Add in i18n/localization support for Metadata Definitions ========================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/metadefs-i18n-support The Glance Metadata Definitions (metadefs) need to be able to display the display-name, titles and descriptions for Namespaces, Objects and Properties in alternate languages. The Metadata Definitions are originally held in JSON files. The JSON files can be loaded into the Glance metadef tables with: glance-manage db_load_metadefs [JSON folder]. Each JSON file represents a specific "namespace" to which Objects and Properties may belong. While there are many other fields in the JSON files, for the purpose of internationalization, just the following fields are relevant: - Namespace.display_name - Namespace.description - Object.description - Object.Properties.title - Object.Properties.description - Properties.title - Properties.description See the example metadef JSON below. Problem Description =================== The internationalization work done for Openstack revolves around Python's support for gettext. To that end oslo has added the oslo_i18n library which encapsulates gettext/ngettext calls. With the oslo_i18n library we can easily add in the typical python '_' wrapper and even _LI, _LW, _LE and _LC wrappers (i.e., log Info, Warning, Error and Critical) wrappers to give the i18n teams the ability to prioritize which strings to translate. Unfortunately, this does not help in the case where the data is held in JSON files, nor does it help if the data is stored in the database. Additionally, the i18n language support is set to a specific language based on when the glance service is started. The metadef data, on the other hand, needs to be completely flexible as Horizon users can change the language view in an ad-hoc nature. Example metadef JSON for the purposes of internationalization: .. code-block:: json { "namespace": "OS::Compute::Test", "display_name": "namespace display name", "description": "Namespace description.", "properties": { "prop_1_name": { "title": "Display name of prop_1", "description": "Description of prop_1.", ... }, "prop_2_name": { "title": "Display name of prop_2", "description": "Description of prop_2.", ... }, ...other properties }, "objects": [ { "name": "Name of object_1", "description": "Description of object_1.", "properties": { "prop_1_object_1": { "title": "Display name of prop_1 of object_1", "description": "Description of prop_1 or object_1.", .... }, "prop_2_object_1": { "title": "Display name of prop_2 of object_1", "description": "Description of prop_2 or object_1.", ... }, ...other object_1 properties... }, }, { "name": "Name of object_2", "description": "Description of object_2.", "properties": { "prop_1_object_2": { "title": "Display name of prop_1 object_2", "description": "Description of prop_1 of object_2.", ... }, ...other object_2 properties... }, }, ...other objects ], "tags": [{"name": "mytag1"}, {"name": "mytag2"}, {"name": "mytag3"}] } Proposed Change =============== Introduce a version of pybabel-json (i.e., pybabel-json-md) to extract the strings of interest from the metadef JSON files and generate a new glance-json-md.pot file. Additionally, the metadef libraries would be modified to translate the specific fields (i.e., display_name, title, description) for list and show commands. A 'locale' option would be supported and set via the requests accept_language setting. If accept_language is set then that language's catalog will attempt to be retrieved, regardless of how the rest of glance is configured from an i18n perspective. No translations will occur if: - the language catalog does not exist - the language catalog exists, but, no matching string is found. - the 'locale' accept_language option is not provided A new environment variable GLANCE_JSON_MD_LOCALEDIR must be defined and it should point to the location where the glance-json-md.mo files will be located (it should be the same value as GLANCE_LOCALEDIR). The environment variable is required in order to use the oslo_i18n libraries. The glance-json-md.pot file would be converted to individual language glance-json-md.po files for translation by the openstack i18n language teams. The project-config git repository would require changes to accommodate the new glance-json-md.pot file. Two files will require adjustment: - common_translation_update.sh - propose_translation_update.sh The glance-pythonclient would require changes to support setting the requests accept_language for list and show commands. Rather than put the metadef strings into the general glance.pot file (or any log related .pot file) a separate glance-json-md.pot file will be introduced. This is necessary, because end users may need to go through internationalization of their own created namespaces (see User Changes below). User Changes ------------ Because the metadef REST API provides a way to update all the fields of interest for translation, the translation catalogs could require manual upkeep. In addition, users could add their own JSON files (i.e., namespaces). In such situations the user would need to generate a new version of the JSON file by using glance-manage db_extract_metadefs and then run the pybabel-json-md extractor against the generated JSON files to create a new glance-json-md.pot file. The user would then take the .pot file and msgmerge it with each language's .po file (i.e., merge the .pot file with all previous language versions). The new .po files will need to have the new translations made. Once that is completed, the .mo files for each language will need to be generated. Alternatively, the user could update an existing metadef JSON file or upload the new metadef file, if it is shareable, in glance's github and wait for the next release. If a user wishes to add a new language translation for a JSON file that is being maintained by the i18n team, they should do so against the new locale's glance-json-md.po file and submit it up to Zanata. In the interim until it is released, they could generate the locale's glance-json-md.mo file and place it in the appropriate locale folder. Alternatives ------------ Alternative 1: Because the metadef JSON data is modifiable by users - do nothing. Alternative 2: - Modify the metadef database schema to allow each language to be stored. See alternative 2 database schema changes below. This would allow for individual langague translations, but, requires keeping all the keys and property details in order across the various languages. - Alter project-config as detailed in the proposed solution. - Use a version of pybabel-json-md to generate a glance-json-md.po file. - Alter the glance-manage command to use each locales glance-json-md.mo file to load the database for each JSON file that is loaded. - Alter the metadef REST API to handle a 'locale' for all (not just list/show) Namespace, Object and Properties functions. - Alter the glance.db.__init__.py for Namespace, Object and Properties to handle the locale correctly with respect to additions, modifications and deletions to ensure all the language versions hold the same set of keys and attributes as the other versions. In particular, the metadef_objects.json_schema properties fields will need to be identical for each object across languages (except for object.properties title and descriptions fields). Similarly, the metadef_properties.json_schema fields would also need to be handled. - Alter the glance.db.sqlalchemy.metadef_api files as needed for the new tables. - Alter python-glanceclient for all commands (not just list/show) to set the requests accept_language setting. Alternative 2 Database Schema Changes: .. code-block:: METADEF_NAMESPACES_I18N namespace_id Primary-Key locale Primary-Key display_name description created_at updated_at METADEF_OBJECTS_I18N object_id Primary-Key locale Primary-Key description json_schema created_at updated_at METADEF_PROPERTIES_I18N property_id Primary-Key locale Primary-Key json_schema created_at updated_at Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Alter the Metadef Namespace, Object and Property API to include a 'locale' option to be specified via the requests accept_language setting for list and show routines. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ There could be a slow down during retrieval of non English metadef Namespace, Object and Property records to pull in the translated strings. Other deployer impact --------------------- Should start the glance service with GLANCE_JSON_MD_LOCALEDIR set. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Wayne Okuma Reviewers --------- - Nikhil Komawar - Ian Cordasco - Flavio Percoco - Stuart McLaren Work Items ---------- * REST API changes * Metadef DB __init__ changes to support locale lookup for Namespace, Object and Property data on list and show commands. * Create a babel plugin to support pybabel-json-md (metadef) data. * Modify babel.cfg to include json-metadef i18n extraction. * Communication with i18n/Transifex teams. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Will need to figure out how to test multi-lingual data. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will need to be provided to indicate possible steps to take if an underlying display_name, title or description field is modified. Those steps would include how to run the version of pybabel-json-md extraction routine so that a merged version of the glance-json.po file could be generated and the steps to provide translation for the merged locale files and then finally how to generate the locale .mo files. References ==========

subject: Add data security related metadata to image
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-02 22:18:47.000000000', 'files': ['specs/mitaka/data-security-metadata.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs/commit/0985bb2f72d33078f8ec71b377be7e9df2dc8c17', 'message': 'Add data security related metadata to image

Enterprises need to be compliant with data security laws and regulations that
require sensitive data to be encrypted at all times. Many OpenStack services
have features (e.g. transparent data encryption in Nova) that can be combined
together to form a data security compliance plan. However, the burden of
verifying that such features have been enabled falls on the operator. We
propose a new metadata category related to data security that can be defined
on an image. This can form the basis of a declarative data security
enforcement model in which this image metadata is used by various OpenStack
services to enforce/enable the data security features that they are capable of.

Change-Id: I386de387ce086e169ab5c76448fb422e39ab96ac
'}]
commit_message:
Add data security related metadata to image

Enterprises need to be compliant with data security laws and regulations that
require sensitive data to be encrypted at all times. Many OpenStack services
have features (e.g. transparent data encryption in Nova) that can be combined
together to form a data security compliance plan. However, the burden of
verifying that such features have been enabled falls on the operator. We
propose a new metadata category related to data security that can be defined
on an image. This can form the basis of a declarative data security
enforcement model in which this image metadata is used by various OpenStack
services to enforce/enable the data security features that they are capable of.

Change-Id: I386de387ce086e169ab5c76448fb422e39ab96ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/79/230679/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== Add data security related metadata to image =========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/data-security-metadata Enterprises need to be compliant with data security laws and regulations that require sensitive data to be encrypted at all times. Many OpenStack services have features (e.g. transparent data encryption in Nova) that can be combined together to form a data security compliance plan. However, the burden of verifying that such features have been enabled falls on the operator. We propose a new metadata category related to data security that can be defined on an image. This can form the basis of a declarative data security enforcement model in which this image metadata is used by various OpenStack services to enforce/enable the data security features that they are capable of. Problem description =================== Most enterprises need to comply with various laws and regulations concerning sensitive data such as credit cards, personally identifiable information, etc. Such laws require that sensitive data be rendered unreadable while at rest (storage) as well as in motion (over the wire). Many OpenStack services have features that the operator can combine to form a comprehensive data security compliance plan. For example, Nova has transparent data encryption and ephemeral storage encryption, among others, which can be turned on to ensure that raw data is not exposed anywhere. However, it is up to the operator to ensure that such features have been enabled. In other words, the operator needs to manually check that nova.conf has ephemeral encryption enabled, that only encrypted Cinder volumes are attached to a VM instance etc. Now, Nova can do these enforcements automatically if only there was a way Nova could know that data security is required for a particular context. We propose a new category of metadata on an image that can be used to inform OpenStack to ensure that all the relevant security features are switched on. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/data-security-enforcements, e.g., describes the proposed enforcements in Nova where this metadata is used to ensure that all data read and written by a VM instance created from this image is encrypted. By providing a simple way of specifying this intent at a single location (i.e. image metadata), this approach can greatly assist the operators tasked with setting up a secure cloud and thereby provide impetus to the enterprise adoption of OpenStack. Proposed change =============== We propose adding a new category of image metadata that will sit with the existing categories. This new category, named "Data Security", will contain three pieces of information: 1) Declaration of a desire for data security 2) The algorithm that need to be used for data encryption 3) The minimum encryption key strength All OpenStack services that partake in data security will ensure that these requirements are met. For example, Nova will reject any request to attach a Cinder volume if the volume is not encrypted and the encryption type of the volume does no use the algorithm and key size specified in the metadata. Note that the enforcement itself is not part of this spec, only the metadata schema is. A demo of proof-of-concept of this spec https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DvnoCTjLuWY was informally discussed at Operators mid-cycle summit in Aug 2015 where it generated some interest among operators. Please see meeting minutes from etherpad: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/PAO-ops-product-wg Alternatives ------------ Not aware of any currently available alternates which can provide these data security related info to the user. Data model impact ----------------- No data model impact; uses existing schema for storing image metadata. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- A deployer needs to set this metadata on an image when the image contains a program that handles sensitive data. The actual values for the metadata properties depend on the deployer's enterprise policies. Developer impact ---------------- This metadata proposed in this blueprint is used to express an intent. As such it is generic and can be used in the context of any OpenStack service or feature. A developer adding a new feature can examine if his/her feature can make data security related choices by making use of this metadata. Implementation ============== Create data-security.json file in glance/etc/metadefs and define the three properties mentioned above. The types and descriptions are as follows: 1) Data security required boolean Declares that any data read/written by any VM instance created from this volume must be secured, including encrypting the data with suitable strong key. 2) Encryption provider string Minimum number of bits in the key used for encrypting data For example, '512' 3) Encryption key size string The encryption algorithm that the data volume attached to a VM instance running this image must be encrypted with For example, 'aes-xts-plain64' Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: dramakri Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): nikhil_k Added Nikhil since we had this discussion with him before on the dev mailing list. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-September/073905.html Other reviewer(s): Any other Glance-spec cores Work Items ---------- Author data-security.json file containing the metadata properties. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Simple tests for loading the json file (for syntax validity) and API-based metadata retrieval. Documentation Impact ==================== The existence, purpose, and use cases for this metadata need to be documented. References ========== 1) Link to operators mid-cycle summit meeting minutes: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/PAO-ops-product-wg 2) Link to the demo of Proof-of-Concept of this feature: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DvnoCTjLuWY

Replace deprecated library function os.popen() with subprocess

subprocess module.

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-16 21:05:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/0927eb160bd40290b298b2a1a9bef47ca93fe2c8', 'message': 'Add keystone::disable_admin_token_auth class

The keystone documentation highly recommends disabling the admin_token
authentication after the initial bootstrap because it exposes a major
attack vector. This patch adds a new class,
keystone::disable_admin_token_auth, which uses ini_subsetting to remove
the admin_token_auth keyword from the pipeline lists.

After the first puppet run, users who use this class with the default
values will need to provide some other way for puppet to authenticate
to keystone. The keystone providers can all read from /root/openrc or
from OS_* environment variables. The openstack_extras::auth_file class
can be used to create the openrc file.

This class must be declared after the main keystone class because it

matter how many times it is activated.

commit_message:
Add keystone::disable_admin_token_auth class

The keystone documentation highly recommends disabling the admin_token
authentication after the initial bootstrap because it exposes a major
attack vector. This patch adds a new class,
keystone::disable_admin_token_auth, which uses ini_subsetting to remove
the admin_token_auth keyword from the pipeline lists.

After the first puppet run, users who use this class with the default
values will need to provide some other way for puppet to authenticate
to keystone. The keystone providers can all read from /root/openrc or
from OS_* environment variables. The openstack_extras::auth_file class
can be used to create the openrc file.

This class must be declared after the main keystone class because it
uses the restart_keystone exec from the main class. This patch moves
this exec out of the $default_domain conditional so that it is
available to reference from the keystone::pipeline class. This is safe
to do because it is a refreshonly exec, so even though it is
unconditionally declared, it will only be activated if the default
domain resource activates it, or the keystone::disable_admin_token_auth
class activates it, or both. It will only restart keystone once no
matter how many times it is activated.

Change-Id: If8a7e1639189f46e16fc996fd7919eb784d24971
Depends-On: Idc3b938e37b792636ec7c2702bf8429467b78d66
(cherry picked from commit 80ae141beba42e4a5a8855a1d3f348868c868b37)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/29/280929/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Remove the admin_token_auth paste pipeline. # After the first puppet run this requires setting keystone v3 # admin credentials via /root/openrc or as environment variables. include keystone::disable_admin_token_auth

commit_message:
Use NVRAM data on VM operations

This change set adds support for setting NVRAM data on newly
created VMs during cold migration, evacuation, and unshelving.
The NVRAM is fetched from the NVRAM store and used on the
create of the VM.

Also in this change, the NVRAM data is deleted when the VM is
deleted from the host if it's determined that the data will
not be needed in the future.  Cases where the data should not
be deleted include:

 - Deleting a VM off the source host when it has been cold
   migrated to a destination host.
 - Deleting a VM that has been shelved since the NVRAM data will
   be needed when it's unshelved.
 - Deleting a VM off the source host when it has been evacuated
   to another host.

Change-Id: I11a2bb2d187e2754c2610f3b7ef69f090cf42fb9

commit_message:
Glare Public (plugin-independent) API

This spec describes a proposed change to the experimental API of Glance
Artifact Repository (aka Glare) to address the number of issues discovered by
OpenStack API Working Group and DefCore committee.

Change-Id: I2a68f35b08571e348f883867e77a13e300b1d4c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/10/254710/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Glare Public (plugin-independent) API ===================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/glare-public-api This spec describes a proposed change to the experimental API of Glance Artifact Repository (aka Glare) to address the number of issues discovered by OpenStack API Working Group and DefCore committee. Problem description =================== The initially proposed EXPERIMENTAL Artifacts API (see its spec at [1]) contained a number of flaws from the point of view of API-WG guidelines [2], as well as had some cross-cloud interoperability issues highlighted by DefCore committee. The API issues include: * Incorrect URI patterns for resource access (URIs contain the state of artifacts, so the artifacts may "move" from one resource to another during their lifecycle) * Incorrect filtering and sorting syntax (it should follow the [3] spec) * Incorrect tags syntax (tags should follow the [4] spec) * Incorrect return codes at some API calls * Incorrect usages of POST and PUT at some API calls * Confusing "type_version" concept (see [5] for more details), making URIs ambiguous Cross-cloud interoperability by DefCore's definition means that the API deployed at different clouds must behave in the same way regardless of the plugins present and optional configuration parameters set. The EXPERIMENTAL Artifacts API at its initial implementation does not follow this principle, as the availability of its URI endpoints depends on the presence of Artifact Type plugins, so the clouds having different plugins installed behave differently. Proposed change =============== This specification aims to solve the described problem by complete refactoring of Glance Artifact Repository API and splitting its calls into two logical groups. One group of calls (covered by this spec) is a Public (or plugin-independent) API, intended to be used by external API consumers of the cloud. This APIs will not depend on the presence of artifact plugins and will always be available in the cloud if it has Glare deployed. This set of calls is intended for user-facing interaction, such as managing the Artifacts from the OpenStack Dashboard, OpenStack CLI or external client code, as well as cross-cloud interactions, such as importing or exporting an artifact from one cloud to another etc (note that the API methods for such import/export actions are not covered by this spec: appropriate methods will be added to the public API later with separate specifications). Another Group of calls (to be described by a separate spec) forms an internal, plugin-based API, intended to be consumed by other OpenStack components deployed within the same cloud with Glare. These OpenStack components will utilise these API calls to work with their "own" artifact types, in a way similar to Nova working with VM images (examples include Murano working with its packages, Heat working with its templates etc). As these API calls are not intended to be made from outside of the cloud, so their cross-cloud interoperability is not required. In this case the API defines a contract between Glare and the project which consumes it internally. Of course, both group of APIs should address all the comments and feedback provided for the first implementation of Glare API and follow the guidelines of API-WG, regardless of being public or internal. Also it worth mentioning that the separation of the API calls is just logical: all these calls are made towards the same root endpoint of Glare API hosted by some service on a specific host: there is no network separation between public and private sets of Glare API. Alternatives ------------ We need to address API-WG comments anyway, so there is no alternatives here. With regard to cross-cloud interoperability there is no rush to do it right now as Glare API is not currently part of DefCore. However, Glance is a core project, and the goal is to make Glare guided by DefCore at some point as well. So, it's better to comply with the DefCore requirements right now, while the API is still experimental and may be changed easily. Data model impact ----------------- This particular spec does not suppose any modifications to the data model. Subsequent changes to Glare API may require such changes (i.e. adding new generic artifact properties), but these should be covered by separate specifications. REST API impact --------------- The version of EXPERIMENTAL Glare API should be bumped from 0.1 to 0.2 to reflect the changes below. Old 0.1 branch may be removed at the same time with the introduction of 0.2 or at any moment afterwards (since it is experimental there is no need for advance warning or deprecation period). The following new methods should be added to the /v0.2 branch * List Artifact Types * Returns a list of deployed and enabled Artifact Type plugins, their versions and description * Method type: GET * HTTP response code: 200, no error codes expected except regular 401 is the request is not authenticated * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifact_types * No parameters, no request body * Response body: a JSON object, containing an array of artifact type descriptors. * List Artifacts * Returns a list of artifacts available in the repository, with optional filtering and sorting. By default (i.e. if no filtering parameters are specified) returns all the artifacts owned by the current tenant (regardless of their state) plus all the public artifacts of other tenants if their state is 'active'. * Method type: GET * Normal HTTP response code: 200 * Expected HTTP error codes: 403 if the `usage` query parameter is passed with the `admin` value while the user is not authorized to perform administrative operations. May also return a regular 401 if the request is not authenticated. * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifacts/all * Parameters: * type, name, state, owner, visibility - allows to filter artifacts by their type, name, state, owner or visibility properties accordingly. The value should either be a string containing a valid value for "equals to" filtering, an expression of form "in:value1,value2,value3" for "in filtering", or an expression of form "neq:value" for "not equals to" filtering. See filtering API guideline [3] for more details. * version - allows to filter artifacts by their version spec. The value should either be a valid semver string (either a complete, eg '1.2.3' or simplified, e.g. '1.0' which is coerced to '1.0.0' automatically) for exact version match, or may include any operators for "in" checks or inequality comparisons. Supported operators are: in, neq, gt, gte, lt and lte. See filtering API guideline [3] for more details. * tags, tags-any, not-tags, not-tags-any - allows various filtering by tag. See Tags API guideline [4] for more details. * usage - if the current user has administrative privileges and the value of this parameter is set to `admin`, the output includes the artifacts owned by other tenants regardless of their state and visibility setting. * limit - the maximum amount of artifacts to be returned by the request. If more artifacts matching the query are present, they may be returned by subsequent requests using the `marker` query parameter. If omitted the default value of 50 is used. * marker - the the id of the last artifact fetched by a "previous page" listing query. The output of this request will contain artifacts which follow the one with the given id. Used for paginated output of artifacts. * sort - allows to sort the output by one or more of the artifacts generic properties. The valid properties for the sorting include: id, name, version (following the semver precedence), type_name, owner, state, visibility, created_at, updated_at, published_at. The value may be passed either a simple string, or followed by a ":asc" or ":desc" suffices for ascending or descending sorting order. Multiple sort values may be specified, separated by commas. See sorting API guideline at [3] for more details. * No request body * Response body: a JSON object, containing an array of Artifact objects. Each Artifact in this array lists only its generic properties, type specific properties, blobs and dependencies are not included. * Get an Artifact by ID * Returns an artifact by its id * Method type: GET * Normal HTTP response code: 200 * Expected HTTP error codes: 404 if the artifact with a given ID is not found or the requesting user is not authorized to access it. * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifacts/all/%id% * URI parameters: * id - identifier of the artifact * No query parameters or request body * Response body: a JSON object containing all the generic properties of the returned artifact. Optionally it may include the type-specific properties, blob- and dependency descriptions, but they should be put into a separate object attribute and no contract assumptions should be made on it, since the set and format of these properties is type specific and is defined by appropriate plugin. * Delete an Artifact * Deletes an artifact specified its id * Method type: DELETE * Normal HTTP response code: 204 * Expected HTTP error codes: * 404 if the artifact with a given ID is not found or the requesting user is not authorized to access it. * 403 if the artifact with a given ID is accessible for the requesting user but the user is not authorized to modify or delete it. * 409 if the artifact cannot be deleted due to violation of some constraint e.g. some other artifact depends on the target artifact with a static checked dependency relation. Same error may also be returned if some custom plugin-defined logic indicates, that this artifact may not be deleted. * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifacts/all/%id% * URI parameters: * id - identifier of the artifact * No query parameters or request body * No response body * Modify an artifact * Changes one or more of the artifact's generic properties. Type-specific properties, blobs or dependency relations may not be set using this method, as they are plugin-based, and so has to be set using the internal API. * Method type: PATCH * Normal HTTP response code: 200 * Expected HTTP error codes: * 404 if the artifact with a given ID is not found or the requesting user is not authorized to access it. * 403 if the artifact with a given ID is accessible for the requesting user but the user is not authorized to modify it. Also returned is the "owner" property is attempted to be changed, but the requesting user is not authorized to perform administrative operations. * 400 if one or more of the patch operations passed in the request attempt to modify a readonly or non-existing property. * 409 if one or more of the patch operations passed in the request attempt to modify an immutable property, while the artifact is already published (i.e. it was already in a "ready" state) by the time when the request was made. Note, that if the artifact is in "draft" state and a single PATCH request contains both changes to immutable properties and a change of "state" to "active", no error will happen. This error code is returned also if the property change is blocked by some custom plugin-defined logic. * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifacts/all/%id% * URI parameters: * id - identifier of the artifact * No query parameters * Request body: a JSON-patch compliant object specified one or more "add", "replace" or "remove" operations targeting any of "name", "version", "description", "tags", "visibility", "state" or "owner" properties. * Get artifact tags * Returns the list of tags of a given artifact. See tag guideline [4] for more details * Method type: GET * Normal HTTP response code: 200 * Expected HTTP error codes: 404 if the artifact with a given ID is not found or the requesting user is not authorized to access it. * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifacts/all/%id%/tags * URI parameters: * id - identifier of the artifact * No query parameters or request body * Response body: a JSON object having "tags" attribute, containing an array of artifact tags * Modify artifacts tags * Sets the list of tags for a given artifact. See tag guideline [4] for more details * Method type: PUT * Normal HTTP response code: 200 * Expected HTTP error codes: * 404 if the artifact with a given ID is not found or the requesting user is not authorized to access it. * 403 if the artifact with a given ID is accessible for the requesting user but the user is not authorized to modify it. * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifacts/all/%id%/tags * URI parameters: * id - identifier of the artifact * No query parameters * Request body: a JSON object having "tags" attribute, containing an array of new artifact tags * Response body: A JSON object having "tags" attribute, containing an array of updated artifact tags * Delete artifacts tags * Clears the list of tags for a given artifact. See tag guideline [4] for more details * Method type: DELETE * Normal HTTP response code: 204 * Expected HTTP error codes: * 404 if the artifact with a given ID is not found or the requesting user is not authorized to access it. * 403 if the artifact with a given ID is accessible for the requesting user but the user is not authorized to modify it. * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifacts/all/%id%/tags * URI parameters: * id - identifier of the artifact * No query parameters, request body or response body * Tag an artifact * Tags an artifact with a given tag. See tag guideline [4] for more details * Method type: PUT * Normal HTTP response code: 201 * Expected HTTP error codes: * 404 if the artifact with a given ID is not found or the requesting user is not authorized to access it. * 403 if the artifact with a given ID is accessible for the requesting user but the user is not authorized to modify it. * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifacts/all/%id%/tags/%value% * URI parameters: * id - identifier of the artifact * value - the value of the tag * No query parameters or request body * No response body. The location header in response should contain the new tags' URL * Check artifact tag * Checks if an artifact is tagged with a given tag. See tag guideline [4] for more details * Method type: GET * Normal HTTP response code: 204 * Expected HTTP error codes: * 404 if the artifact with a given ID is not found or the requesting user is not authorized to access it or if the artifact does not have the specified tag * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifacts/all/%id%/tags/%value% * URI parameters: * id - identifier of the artifact * value - the value of the tag * No query parameters, request body or response body * Untag an artifact * Removes a given tag from the artifact. See tag guideline [4] for more details * Method type: DELETE * Normal HTTP response code: 204 * Expected HTTP error codes: * 404 if the artifact with a given ID is not found or the requesting user is not authorized to access it or if the artifact does not have the specified tag * 403 if the artifact with a given ID is accessible for the requesting user but the user is not authorized to modify it. * Resource URL: /v0.2/artifacts/all/%id%/tags/%value% * URI parameters: * id - identifier of the artifact * value - the value of the tag * No query parameters, request body or response body. Security impact --------------- No security impact Notifications impact -------------------- No notification impact Other end user impact --------------------- The new API will need the support in python-glanceclient. The support of the Glare API v0.1 may be removed from python-glanceclient at the same moment when v0.2 support is added or at any moment afterwards (since it is experimental there is no need for advance warning or deprecation period). Performance Impact ------------------ No performance impact Other deployer impact --------------------- No deployer impact Developer impact ---------------- Since the Glare API is EXPERIMENTAL, developers should be prepared to the breaking changes in it. This change is definitely breaking, but it was announced long ago, so we should proceed with it freely. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ativelkov Other contributors: mfedosin kkushaev dshakhray Reviewers --------- FastTrack review process Core reviewer(s): nikhil-komawar Work Items ---------- * Add new API router and controllers * Write helper methods to implement query parameter parsing (e.g. for filtering, sorting, tags etc, according to guidelines) * Cover new APIs with unittest * Set v0.1 API as deprecated. * Add v0.2 client to python-glanceclient Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= The new API should be covered with the functional tests Documentation Impact ==================== Since the API is EXPERIMENTAL its detailed documentation is not needed, however the work to document it properly should be started to ensure that it is covered with complete docs by the time we are ready to consider it stable. References ========== [1] Initial spec: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/kilo/artifact-repository.html [2] Summary of API issues identified by API-WG: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/glance-artifacts-api-issues [3] Filtering and sorting API-WG guideline: http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/pagination_filter_sort.html [4] Tags API-WG guideline: https://github.com/openstack/api-wg/blob/master/guidelines/tags.rst [5] Description of type-version issue https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/glance-v3-open-issues

commit_message:
Add more implementation details to 'deprecate-v3-api' spec

Initially the spec contained just the description of the v3 API
removal, without any details on where the code being removed should go
and how the glance artifacts service will be run after it's removed
from the main glance-api.

This patch covers this gap by adding appropriate descriptions into the
'Proposed change' and 'Work Items' blocks.

Change-Id: Iac8f149d81e6877021364fe84dd45d8aa91049a9
Targets-blueprint: deprecate_v3_api
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/27/259427/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This will start an independent series of the API versions for Artifacts API. The first stable version should obviously be a v1, however since the current version is not stable yet and is likely to be frequently changed, so it's better to have its version as v0.x. The code being renamed from glance v3 will be called "artifacts v0.1", with further revisions incrementing the minor version, all the way till the API is stable, then it will be renamed to v1. Usually the URI prefix includes only the major versions of the API (e.g. v1, v2), but this is usually done by the microversioning inside the controller, since minor versions of APIs are usually backwards compatible. With the experimental API this is not the case, e.g. v0.2 may be completely incompatible with v0.1. Because of this, it was decided to include the minor version of the API into the URI prefix, so the calls to the version 0.1 of artifacts API will be made to `http://host:port/v0.1/...` The api controller code needs to be moved from the `glance/api/v3` directory to `glance/api/artifacts/v0`, and all the references to old v3 locations should be removed from the paste configuration at `glance-api-paste.ini` However, since the paste configuration is often retained when updating the openstack deployments, glance api should still work with the previous (released in Liberty) `glance-api-paste.ini` config. So, a placeholder controller should be put into the `glance/api/v3` directory in the case if the old paste config still references it. This controller should log a deprecation warning (so the deployers are aware about the change and can modify the outdated paste config) and redirect all the requests targeting the removed glance v3 to the newly added artifacts v0.1. The python-glanceclient should be updated as well to change the version of the client class from the glance v3 to glance artifact v0 It's also required to update the glance devstack script to add an ability of running artifacts service in devstack deployements. The script should create a new screen session to run the service, configure its .conf and paste.ini files and register the running service in keystone service catalog. The service type in keystone should be 'artifacts', service name - 'glare' (this is an acronym for GLance Artifact REpository) and service description - 'Glance Artifact Service'. In devstack artifact service should listen on port 9494. If these are not removed, a deprecation warning will be logged and the old /v3 controller of glance-api will do the redirects to the new artifacts service endpoint if the one is registered in keystone service catalog. * ativelkov * dshakray * agalkin * mfedosin* modify the client code from glanceclient/v3 to glanceclient/glare/v0 in python-glanceclient, as well as change the URI prefixes in the appropriate client calls; * modify the devstack deployment script to properly configure glance-artifacts service, register it in keystone service catalog and run in separate screen session.
deleted_lines: * dshakray * mfedosin* ativelkov

revisions:

commit_message:
Document how to use loopback devices for Swift

People commonly want to use loopback devices to evaulate or develop on
Swift.  The steps for this are slightly different than those for
physical block devices.

Also make some small fix ups to the title formatting.

Change-Id: I0c1cb4a261f264dc56bd065ab137e5ee79e773f8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/09/290009/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Disks with a partition table (recommended) ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~For evaluation, loopback devices can be used in lieu of real disks: :: index=0 for d in sdc sdd sde; do free_device=$(losetup -f) fallocate -l 1G /tmp/$d losetup $free_device /tmp/$d parted $free_device -s -- mklabel gpt mkpart KOLLA_SWIFT_DATA 1 -1 sudo mkfs.xfs -f -L d${index} ${free_device}p1 (( index++ )) done Disks without a partition table ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Rings
deleted_lines: disks with partition table (recommended) ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~disks without partition table ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~rings

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/67/289867/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | Ubuntu has 4 different 'components' - main, universe, multiverse and restricted: * Main: Officially supported software. * Restricted: Supported software that is not available under a completely free license. * Universe: Community maintained software, i.e. not officially supported software. * Multiverse: Software that is not free. The default apt sources configuration is now set to only include the ``main`` and ``universe`` components as those are the only required components for a functional deployment. If deployers wish to include other components then the variable ``lxc_container_template_apt_components`` may be set in ``/etc/openstack_deploy/user_variables.yml`` with the full list of desired components. upgrade: - | Ubuntu has 4 different 'components' - main, universe, multiverse and restricted: * Main: Officially supported software. * Restricted: Supported software that is not available under a completely free license. * Universe: Community maintained software, i.e. not officially supported software. * Multiverse: Software that is not free. The default apt sources configuration is now set to only include the ``main`` and ``universe`` components as those are the only required components for a functional deployment. If deployers wish to include other components then the variable ``lxc_container_template_apt_components`` may be set in ``/etc/openstack_deploy/user_variables.yml`` with the full list of desired components.

dump a release tracking dashboard

Provides 2 modes, CSV and "etherpad" (a hierarchical text view). It
isn't clear which is going to be easier to use for tracking.

commit_message:
Enable developer mode

This commit adds the ability to install cinder without a repo server.
This pattern is lifted from the os_keystone role and allows us to
further develop functional testing for this role.

Change-Id: I85ba753a946b22ee3e9b9403977501a1804f9d86
Partial-Bug: #1553967

commit_message:
Enable developer mode

This commit adds the ability to install nova without a repo server.
This pattern is lifted from the os_keystone role and allows us to
further develop functional testing for this role.

Change-Id: Ifb1c4140a33dc1d3de7f0f2741e51191efd989db

subject: VPNaaS Fix bandit Jinja issue
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-08 01:37:43.000000000', 'files': ['neutron_vpnaas/services/vpn/device_drivers/ipsec.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/commit/c5dd3df40541aefea570fc81793d4d99c44706dc', 'message': 'VPNaaS Fix bandit Jinja issue

The Bandit security scan identifies that the Jinja session loader
does not set autoescape to True if the global JINJA_ENV not set,
which increases risk of injection via the config template file.

>> Issue: [jinja2_autoescape_false] By default, jinja2 sets autoescape
to False. Consider using autoescape=True to mitigate XSS vulnerabilities.
   Severity: High   Confidence: High
   Location: neutron_vpnaas/services/vpn/device_drivers/ipsec.py:111

Fixing by setting true.

Scan can be reproduced by downloading the bandit package and running from
neutron-vpnaas directory:
bandit -r neutron_vpnaas -ll -ii

Change-Id: I136704a769fc29f797104f87ced1fa205b3439c7
'}]
commit_message:
VPNaaS Fix bandit Jinja issue

The Bandit security scan identifies that the Jinja session loader
does not set autoescape to True if the global JINJA_ENV not set,
which increases risk of injection via the config template file.

>> Issue: [jinja2_autoescape_false] By default, jinja2 sets autoescape
to False. Consider using autoescape=True to mitigate XSS vulnerabilities.
   Severity: High   Confidence: High
   Location: neutron_vpnaas/services/vpn/device_drivers/ipsec.py:111

Fixing by setting true.

Scan can be reproduced by downloading the bandit package and running from
neutron-vpnaas directory:
bandit -r neutron_vpnaas -ll -ii

Change-Id: I136704a769fc29f797104f87ced1fa205b3439c7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas refs/changes/49/289649/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: JINJA_ENV = jinja2.Environment(loader=templateLoader, autoescape=True)
deleted_lines: JINJA_ENV = jinja2.Environment(loader=templateLoader)

commit_message:
Add vexxhost and osic Ubuntu mirror configs to gate check

Two new providers have been added to OpenStack-CI's list of nodepool
providers. This patch ensures that we have an appropriate apt mirror
configured if the gate job runs on one of those providers.

Change-Id: I39d39d413fd4eb4dfa05809c6de12e417f8d0002
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/54/289954/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The nodepool provider list can be found in: # https://github.com/openstack-infra/project-config/blob/master/nodepool/nodepool.yaml "vexxhost-ca-ymq-1"*) export UBUNTU_REPO="http://ubuntu.mirror.vexxhost.com/ubuntu" ;; "osic-cloud1"*) export UBUNTU_REPO="http://iad.mirror.rackspace.com/ubuntu" ;;

commit_message:
Allow for usage of pre-allocated IPs for the management network

Id3d4f12235501ae77200430a2dc022f378dce336 added support for pre-allocated
IPs on the other overlay networks, but because the patch adding the
managment network (I0813a13f60a4f797be04b34258a2cffa9ea7e84f) was
under review around the same time, we missed adding the from_pool
capability to the ManagementNetwork.

Change-Id: If99f37634d5da7e7fb7cfc31232e926bd5ff074a
(cherry picked from commit 07e99fef9ba96dd9a650ef43560e6a7794939a20)

The "Scaling backup service" patch [1] in Cinder (merged a couple of days

This patch addresses this issue. The patch introduces a new class called
`ScalityRemoteFsClient` which inherits from `RemoteFsClient`. We can't
strictly use the `RemoteFsClient` because how to mount Scality FS is

commit_message:
Fix Scality SOFS support

The "Scaling backup service" patch [1] in Cinder (merged a couple of days
ago) uses os-brick to perform a local attach volume. It revealed that the
support for Scality SOFS in os-brick was broken. (we did have a CI in
Cinder but the os-brick code path was not fully exercised until [1] merged).

This patch addresses this issue. The patch introduces a new class called
`ScalityRemoteFsClient` which inherits from `RemoteFsClient`. We can't
strictly use the `RemoteFsClient` because how to mount Scality FS is
a bit different from other FS.

Note that without this patch, the Scality Cinder driver is broken, more
precisely cinder backup is broken. So I would appreciate if we can merge
that for Mitaka (which needs another minor/micro(?) release of os-brick)

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/262395/

Change-Id: Icfa09b124d252d1d6b07d9cff8c63c7c0d65cc30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/82/285382/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: mount_type_lower = mount_type.lower() if mount_type_lower == 'scality': cls = remotefs.ScalityRemoteFsClient else: cls = remotefs.RemoteFsClient self._remotefsclient = cls(mount_type, root_helper, execute=execute, *args, **kwargs)
deleted_lines: mount_type_lower = mount_type.lower() self._remotefsclient = remotefs.RemoteFsClient(mount_type, root_helper, execute=execute, *args, **kwargs)

commit_message:
Time to get rid of any last vestiges of slave_of

The controller (apischema and instance controller) have long
understood that slave_of is going away and has supported
replica_of. Getting rid of the slave_of in the client is now one part
of this final 'cleansing'. Look for a corresponding commit on the
controller side which will clean up the rest of it. That commit is
I87c8a14c06fa5df60ea3ed6b09412dc32fafcec7 and the URL for that review
is https://review.openstack.org/#/c/245845/

Change-Id: I9b905716b704ea9ec9332b48b05c49cccbd04c8b
Partial-Bug: #1461196
Depends-On: I87c8a14c06fa5df60ea3ed6b09412dc32fafcec7

commit_message:
Fix issues with test_package_ordering unit test

The test_package_ordering.sh test is failing intermittently because it
doesn't always ignore case, or use a dictionary sort.

This patch changes the sort to use dictionary sort and ignore case (-df)
which should ensure the test is more consistent, regardless of sort
version, and other inconsistencies.

Additionally the rpms-suse/horizon file order was changed to abide by
this consistency.

Change-Id: I5ba46a7faa837208a98c26b4831673e7c7f43c88
Closes-Bug: #1554488

commit_message:
Add all isolated networks to all nodes.

This change allows every overcloud node to optionally participate in
any of the isolated networks. The optional networks are not enabled
by default, but allow additional flexibility. Since the new networks
are not enabled by default, the standared deployment is unchanged.
This change was originally requested for OpenDaylight support.

There are several use cases for using non-standard networks.
For instance, one example might be adding the Internal API network
to the Ceph nodes, in order to use that network for administrative
functions. Another example would be adding the Storage Management
network to the compute nodes, in order to use it for backup. Without
this change, any deviation from the standard set of roles that use a
network is a custom change to the Heat templates, which makes
upgrades much more difficult.

Change-Id: Ia386c964aa0ef79e457821d8d96ebb8ac2847231
(cherry picked from commit 41b3682f65d2eb0e60d920492d7eb0b53de3a020)

commit_message:
Honor comments for translators when extracting messages

To extract commments for translators, '--add-comments' option
must be passed to pybabel. Comments for translators were extracted
when we used Django tools to extract messages, but when we switched
to pybabel it was lost. This commit adds the option to run_tests.sh.

Move the place of existing comments for translators
so that pybabel can find them. Django tool and pybabel
expect a bit different places.
Also add comments to ungettext_lazy in test codes.

Closes-Bug: #1553581
Change-Id: Ia2df36dfebb59bede19d57b2158a907126ca1944

Use interpolate in JS to allow translators to control word order

String concatenation is not recommended for better translation.

Closes-Bug: #1553619

commit_message:
get rid of most vestiges of slave_of

moving this Change-Id: I87c8a14c06fa5df60ea3ed6b09412dc32fafcec7 to
stable/kilo to resolve the gate because the troveclient has removed

Closes-Bug: #1538506

commit_message:
Uncouple lbaas object models from neutron core plugin results

Since I6e1ef53d7aae7d04a5485810cc1db0a8eb125953, subnets have
'description' field. We should accommodate for it on lbaas side.

Instead of introducing yet another field for lbaas object, make base
class filter out unknown fields in from_dict() before passing them into
__init__.

Change-Id: Ib00f61cfbc13bf934c31eb476039728830e79e92
Closes-Bug: #1554076

commit_message:
libvirt: add policy check to avoid using qga in realtime context

Adds a policy check to avoid using qemu guest agent in a realtime
context. We shoud to leading to a very minimal hardware support for
guest.

Blueprint: libvirt-real-time
Change-Id: I7a48fb4fd57d45a2ef7cb57f1c7a727938c80e56

commit_message:
libvirt: introduce block_stats to return device stats

This commit add method block_stats to guest and make it to return a
object BlocStats. It also updates driver to make it to take account
about that new change.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-clean-driver
Change-Id: I3d01a24347ce6045692dd8fc1809dd89ff6386a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/88/251288/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def block_stats(self, path): """Returns block devices statistiques :param path: Path of block device :returns: BlockStats object """ stats = self._domain.blockStats(path) return BlockStats( rd_req=stats[0], rd_bytes=stats[1], wr_req=stats[2], wr_bytes=stats[3], flush_ops=stats[4]) class BlockStats(object): def __init__(self, rd_req, rd_bytes, wr_req, wr_bytes, flush_ops): """Block device statistics information :param rd_read: Read requested :param rd_bytes: Total size of read in bytes :param wr_read: Write requested :param wr_bytes: Total size of write in bytes :param flush_ops: Total of flush operation """ self.rd_req = rd_req self.rd_bytes = rd_bytes self.wr_req = wr_req self.wr_bytes = wr_bytes self.flush_ops = flush_ops def to_list(self): return [self.rd_req, self.rd_bytes, self.wr_req, self.wr_bytes, self.flush_ops]

commit_message:
libvirt: introduce exceptions handler

Aims of this first commit is to isolate libvirt exception from virt
from nova common exceptions.

Change-Id: I84c1de059b3427491b984711a60ba804660d3afe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/91/257991/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Red Hat, Inc # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Manages libvirt exceptions. This class encapsulates libvirt error and provides certain higher level APIs around. """ import functools from nova.i18n import _ from nova.virt import exception libvirt = None libvirt_error = None class LibvirtException(exception.VirtException): msg_fmt = _("libvirt error: %(error_code)s %(error_message)s") def __init__(self, exc, **kwargs): super(exception.VirtException, self).__init__( error_code=exc.get_error_code(), error_message=exc.get_error_message()) def code(self): return self.kwargs['error_code'] def message(): return self.kwargs['error_message'] def is_code(self, code): return self.code() class LibvirtInternalError(LibvirtException): msg_fmt = _("Internal error") class LibvirtSystemError(LibvirtException): msg_fmt = _("General system cause failure") class LibvirtNoDomain(LibvirtException): msg_fmt = _("Domain not found or unexpectedly disappeared") class LibvirtOperationTimeout(LibvirtException): msg_fmt = _("Timeout occurred during operation") class LibvirtOperationFailed(LibvirtException): msg_fmt = _("Command to hypervisor failed") class LibvirtOperationInvalid(LibvirtException): msg_fmt = _("Operation is not applicable at this time") class LibvirtConfigUnsupported(LibvirtException): msg_fmt = _("Command to hypervisor failed") class LibvirtNoSupport(LibvirtException): msg_fmt = _("No support for this function") def exceptions_handler(exc): global libvirt, libvirt_errors if libvirt is None: libvirt = importutils.import_module('libvirt') if libvirt_error is None: libvirt_errors = { libvirt.VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR: LibvirtInternalError, libvirt.VIR_ERR_SYSTEM_ERROR: LibvirtSystemError, libvirt.VIR_ERR_NO_DOMAIN: LibvirtNoDomain, libvirt.VIR_ERR_OPERATION_TIMEOUT: LibvirtOperationTimeout, libvirt.VIR_ERR_OPERATION_FAILED: LibvirtOperationFailed, libvirt.VIR_ERR_CONFIG_UNSUPPORTED: LibvirtConfigUnsupported, libvirt.VIR_ERR_NO_SUPPORT: LibvirtNoSupport, } if isinstance(exc, libvirt.libvirtError): errcode = exc.get_error_code() if errcode in libvirt_errors: raise libvirt_errors[errcode](exc) raise LibvirtException(exc) raise exc def catch_libvirt_error(function): @functools.wraps(function) def decorated_function(*args, **kwargs): try: return function(*args, **kwargs) except Exception as exc: exceptions_handler(exc) return decorated_function

commit_message:
conductor: initialize request_spec to handle expected exception

populate_retry is only doing arithmetic without to interact with third
parts and can throw an *expected* exception where
'build_request_spec()' not. This change initializes request_spec soon
as possible since it's used in case where that *expected* exception is
raised.

Change-Id: I4e72b0bcff9edc5536f3c9185b2233be5875e614

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/i18n refs/changes/09/289009/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: To build the translated document, you need update the file ``doc-tools-check-languages.conf`` in each repository, and add a declaration to BOOKS like ``["ja"]="install-guide"``. For stable release document, such as Installtion Guide for Liberty, you need directly update the file ``doc-tools-check-languages.conf`` in stable branch. To add a link to the generalated document, you need update the file ``www/<lang>/index.html`` in the ``openstack-manuals`` repository. Note that the web pages are published from ``master`` branch, which contains the pages for all releases, such as Liberty. Therefore, you don't need update the stable branch. Developer documentation ----------------------- Currently, we do not have translation feature for developer documents: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/<project>
deleted_lines: TBD: How to enable translated document generation for your language and add links to the above index pages. At the moment, ask it in the i18n mailing list.

commit_message:
Malformed user access sql for postgres guest agent

The postgresql guest agent creates a malformed sql statement
when attempting to retrieve or modify the list of users with
access to the DB.

Change-Id: I87d3a71b4b567707561dd8110b3f80f8095f95bb
Fixes-bug: 1543816

commit_message:
Fix default value on globals for config_strategy

In kolla/ansible/group_vars/all.yml config_strategy is COPY_ALWAYS
In kolla/etc/kolla/globals.yml the default value shown is COPY_ONCE

TrivialFix

Change-Id: If7000b811715c6cb84af3539cb522c22d31dc03b

commit_message:
Add script and playbook to test dhcp

It will run a play where it will spin up five vms, and will
truncate inventory to consider only three. The play will
configure dns using dynamic inventory, and will take an
extra parameter to specify if we want static ips or not.
It will perform a test on dnsmasq leases file, to ensure that
the dhcp behaviour is working as expected, depending on
the settings.

Change-Id: If56488f78524ceba201b50f76df306620744cda5

commit_message:
Adding ManagementIpSubnet to linux bridge net conf

Because of the new ManagementIpSubnet parameter (introduced by the
15bb6726 commit), the net-config-linux-bridge network configuration file
must be updated.

Change-Id: I020692eedd9a96e28d0b871e2c27b4f0ee87e3fa
(cherry picked from commit b7f382492939816e4bc928cc6892b8f789701fac)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/02/287602/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ManagementIpSubnet: default: '' description: IP address/subnet on the management network type: string

commit_message:
Added +2 release names for versionutils

The default value for remove_in for versionutils.deprecated is 2,
yet the names of the next two releases following Mitaka are not
defined in the _RELEASES dict. This provides the release name
for Mitaka deprecated functionality.

Change-Id: Ia5fd07d152b590d78e45f4765edef1c9aea7e526
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log refs/changes/54/288754/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('oslo_log.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_mitaka_plus_two(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.MITAKA, remove_in=+2) class OutdatedClass(object): pass obj = OutdatedClass() self.assertIsInstance(obj, OutdatedClass) self.assert_deprecated(mock_reporter, what='OutdatedClass()', as_of='Mitaka', remove_in='Ocata') @mock.patch('oslo_log.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_newton_plus_two(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.NEWTON, remove_in=+2) class OutdatedClass(object): pass obj = OutdatedClass() self.assertIsInstance(obj, OutdatedClass) self.assert_deprecated(mock_reporter, what='OutdatedClass()', as_of='Newton', remove_in='P')

commit_message:
Fixes a few LDAP tests to actually run

It looks like the original intent of overriding these test methods was
to actually make the test run. The direct parent, BaseLDAPIdentity, was
overriding them from its parent in order to show they raise an
exception. The modified test class tests the fix for this behavior and
want to execute the original test, not the overridden one. Unfortunately
the test method was never actually called.

Change-Id: Ib312e75f5a61ef7518177608acce56dfdc05afbf

commit_message:
Remove explicit use of asserts

The Bandit linter flagged code using the assert function. This
removes the assert and ensures an exception is thrown with
another call.

Change-Id: I582e0985e46414f97bd15d6d763bae132de7c12a

deleted_lines: try: assert False except exceptions.VimFaultException as ex: ex.fault_list) try: assert False except exceptions.VimFaultException as ex: self.assertEqual(fault_list, ex.fault_list)

commit_message:
Beef up Barbican Validation

This patch disallows properties which have nothing to do with
Barbican Object and sets limits to certiain properties.
Passing additional properties causes confusion to the user.

Example: When passing metadata for secret creation if it
looks like:
{
"name": "all mine"
"junk": "some junk"
}

an error will be thrown as follows:
HTTPBadRequest: Provided object does not match schema 'Secret':
Additional properties are not allowed (u'name' was unexpected).

Change-Id: I0fd927bcd3da79c5f13c1ac334eb1826b85669cf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/84/262684/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use a set of Sahara plugin in all supported version

This set of plugin is in all supported versions of Sahara:
hdp was removed from Mitaka, but cdh was available also in
previous versions

This allows tests which do not configure tempest to pass.

Change-Id: I4ff925c8e34683186a028e6a4e933302c26a41e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/74/289974/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default=["vanilla", "cdh"],
deleted_lines: default=["vanilla", "hdp"],

commit_message:
Monasca-setup to configure for instance scale_group metadata

Fix to enable instance scale_group metadata dimension in libvirt
plugin to support monasca based autoscaling.

Change-Id: Ia7c51091c6a07105f6d9e295957ad7bf724e004e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/21/286721/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # List of instance metadata keys to be sent as dimensions # By default 'scale_group' metadata is used here for supporting auto # scaling in Heat. metadata = ['scale_group'] 'vm_probation': vm_probation, 'metadata': metadata}
deleted_lines: 'vm_probation': vm_probation}

The default balance-tcp is causing issues with deployments.
Defaulting to active-backup.

After ~ 100 guests (total) connectivity to each guest would become spotty

For more details, refer to this link:

commit_message:
Change default bond-mode

The default balance-tcp is causing issues with deployments.
Defaulting to active-backup.

After ~ 100 guests (total) connectivity to each guest would become spotty
(simple pings would fail, then become successful.) In /var/log/messages
we saw :
"overcloud-controller-1 kernel: openvswitch: ovs-system: deferred action
limit reached, drop recirc action"

For more details, refer to this link:
http://openvswitch.org/pipermail/discuss/2015-October/019168.html

Change-Id: Ia0f2592a289e13472b98d97057cd516c5048fe59
(cherry picked from commit 215cf39c709419f018be02b208af10f2bd4c772e)

Make function _bind_port_if_needed to bind at least one time when the port's

This is the second attempt to introduce the patch (the first one was

commit_message:
Add the rebinding chance in _bind_port_if_needed

Make function _bind_port_if_needed to bind at least one time when the port's
binding status passed in is already in binding_failed.

This is the second attempt to introduce the patch (the first one was
reverted due to regression that broke Ironic), now with proper
notification sent even when binding attempt failed.

The patch also fixes several cases when we attempted to notify with a
binding context that was not committed into database.

The patch changes _attempt_binding to call _commit_port_binding only
with the binding final state:
1. Successful binding: will just call _commit_port_binding.
2. Unsuccessful binding: will call _commit_port_binding at the final
attempt to bind the port.
This is in order to refrain from reverts, with will really complicate
things even  more.

Co-Authored-By: Yalei Wang <yalei.wang@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Nir Magnezi <nmagnezi@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Schwarz <jschwarz@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I437290affd8eb87177d0626bf7935a165859cbdd
Closes-Bug: #1399249
(cherry picked from commit 63fe3a418c685ca90077f1dd4c35fd9ccf586fca)

commit_message:
Add tests for trust using impersonation

Keystone is missing trust test cases using impersonation.
This patch adds some test to verify the basic functionality
for trust when impersonation is set to True.

Change-Id: I5126873cd3b25ae8978c2ffaae050ac5b2cd5701
Closes-Bug: 1538626
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/79/273279/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.tests.unit import utils as test_utilsclass TestTrustImpersonation(test_v3.RestfulTestCase): """Impersonation with trust Impersonation allows the trustor to optionally delegate impersonation abilities to the trustee. To services validating the token, the trustee will appear as the trustor, although the token will also contain the impersonation object to indicate that this behavior is in effect. """ def config_overrides(self): super(TestTrustImpersonation, self).config_overrides() self.config_fixture.config( group='trust', enabled=True, allow_redelegation=True, max_redelegation_count=3 ) def setUp(self): super(TestTrustImpersonation, self).setUp() # Create a trustee self.trustee_user = unit.create_user(self.identity_api, domain_id=self.domain_id) # trustor->trustee self.trust_ref = unit.new_trust_ref( trustor_user_id=self.user_id, trustee_user_id=self.trustee_user['id'], project_id=self.project_id, impersonation=True, expires=dict(minutes=2), role_ids=[self.role_id], allow_redelegation=True) # Create trust resp = self.post('/OS-TRUST/trusts', body={'trust': self.trust_ref}) self.trust = self.assertValidTrustResponse(resp) auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=self.trustee_user['id'], password=self.trustee_user['password'], trust_id=self.trust['id']) self.trust_token = self.get_requested_token(auth_data) def test_token_attributes_on_impersonated_token(self): response = self.get('/auth/tokens', headers={'X-Subject-Token': self.trust_token}, expected_status=http_client.OK) resp_json = json.loads(response.body) # Assert user on trusted token equals the trustor self.assertEqual(self.user['id'], resp_json['token']['user']['id']) self.assertEqual(self.user['name'], resp_json['token']['user']['name']) # Assert role on trusted token self.assertEqual(self.role['id'], resp_json['token']['roles'][0]['id']) self.assertEqual(self.role['name'], resp_json['token']['roles'][0]['name']) # Assert trustor and trustee on trusted token self.assertEqual( self.user['id'], resp_json['token']['OS-TRUST:trust']['trustor_user']['id']) self.assertEqual( self.trustee_user['id'], resp_json['token']['OS-TRUST:trust']['trustee_user']['id']) def test_trustee_access_level(self): auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=self.trustee_user['id'], password=self.trustee_user['password']) # Get trustee token to make admin calls trustee_token = self.get_requested_token(auth_data) # Attempt to list user with trustee's token self.get('/users', token=trustee_token, expected_status=http_client.FORBIDDEN) # Verify that trust token can list users self.get('/users', token=self.trust_token, expected_status=http_client.OK) @test_utils.wip('This will fail because of bug #1534834. There is no real' 'use case for creating a new trust using impersonation.') def test_trust_creation_with_trust_token(self): """Attempt to create a new trust with a trust token using impersonation and setting trustor on trust to match the original trustor's id. """ # Create a trustee trustee_user_2 = unit.create_user(self.identity_api, domain_id=self.domain_id) # trustor->trustee trust_ref = unit.new_trust_ref( trustor_user_id=self.user_id, trustee_user_id=trustee_user_2['id'], project_id=self.project_id, impersonation=False, expires=dict(minutes=1), role_ids=[self.role_id], allow_redelegation=False, redelegated_trust_id=self.trust['id']) # Create trust with trust token using impersonation should fail. # FIXME(jorge_munoz) This should return bad request, but returns # a valid 200 OK. Bug 1534834 self.post('/OS-TRUST/trusts', body={'trust': trust_ref}, token=self.trust_token, expected_status=http_client.BAD_REQUEST)

commit_message:
Fix hyperv use of deprecated network_api_class

Hyperv driver had some residual use of network_api_class after it was
deprecated in the core. This makes hyperv use nova.network.is_neutron
for selecting its network drivers.

Change-Id: Icfcafd031a793a4713c2997adc5c84bb9c9864fe
Closes-Bug: #1554059

commit_message:
Add documentation for two-VIP and TLS blueprints

Relates-to: blueprint kolla-ssl

Change-Id: Id82d22c2195be5d897c781f28087a1ea422b8bea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/62/289662/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Endpoint Network Configuration ------------------------------ When an OpenStack cloud is deployed, each services' REST API is presented as a series of endpoints. These endpoints are the admin URL, the internal URL, and the external URL. Kolla offers two options for assigning these endpoints to network addresses. These are combined and separate. For the combined option, all three endpoints share the same IP address. For the separate option, the external URL is assigned a different IP address as the internal and admin IP address. The configuration parameters related to these options are: - kolla_internal_vip_address - network_interface - kolla_external_vip_address - kolla_external_vip_interface For the combined option, set these two variables, while allowing the other to accept their default values. In this configuration all REST API requests, internal and external, will flow over the same network. :: kolla_internal_vip_address: "10.10.10.254" network_interface: "eth0" For the separate option, set these four variables. In this configuration the internal and external REST API requests can flow over separate networks. :: kolla_internal_vip_address: "10.10.10.254" network_interface: "eth0" kolla_external_vip_address: "10.10.20.254" kolla_external_vip_interface: "eth1" TLS Configuration ----------------- An additional endpoint configuration option is to enable or disable TLS protection for the external VIP. TLS allows a client to authenticate the OpenStack service endpoint and allows for encryption of the requests and responses. .. NOTE:: The kolla_internal_vip_address and kolla_external_vip_address must be different to enable TLS on the external network. The configuration variables that control TLS networking are: - kolla_enable_tls_external - kolla_external_fqdn_cert The default for TLS is disabled; to enable TLS networking: :: kolla_enable_tls_external: "yes" kolla_external_fqdn_cert: "{{ node_config_directory }}/certificates/mycert.pem" Two certificate files are required to use TLS securely with authentication. These two files will be provided by your Certificate Authority. These two files are the server certificate with private key and the CA certificate with any intermediate certificates. The server certificate needs to be installed with the kolla deployment and is configured with the kolla_external_fqdn_cert parameter. If the server certificate provided is not already trusted by the client, then the CA certificate file will need to be distributed to the client. When using TLS to connect to a public endpoint, an OpenStack client will have settings similar to this: :: export OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID=default export OS_USER_DOMAIN_ID=default export OS_PROJECT_NAME=demo export OS_USERNAME=demo export OS_PASSWORD=demo-password export OS_AUTH_URL=https://mykolla.example.net:5000 export OS_CACERT=/etc/pki/mykolla-cacert.crt export OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION=3 Self-Signed Certificates ------------------------ .. NOTE:: Self-signed certificates should never be used in production. It is not always practical to get a certificate signed by a well-known trust CA, for example a development or internal test kolla deployement. In these cases it can be useful to have a self-signed certificate to use. For convenience, the kolla-ansible command will generate the necessary certificate files based on the information in the globals.yml configuration file. :: kolla-ansible certificates The files haproxy.pem and haproxy-ca.pem will be generated and stored in the /etc/kolla/certificates/ directory. Fully Qualified Domain Name Configuration ----------------------------------------- When addressing a server on the internet, it is more common to use a name, like www.example.net, instead of an address like 10.10.10.254. If you prefer to use names to address the endpoints in your kolla deployement use the variables: - kolla_internal_fqdn - kolla_external_fqdn :: kolla_internal_fqdn: inside.mykolla.example.net kolla_external_fqdn: mykolla.example.net

commit_message:
Change the CinderISCSIHelper to lioadm

Previously we used to always set CinderISCSIHelper to lioadm from
the client. With [1] we aim at cleaning up the client from any
default so this change move the actual default into the templates.

Change-Id: Iabc94ad1cce6f1744429aca9f866a59a698f5680
Related-Bug: 1554564
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/10/290010/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: default: tgtadm
